, monkfish liver with redfish on top and anago nigiri (saltwater eel instead of unagi (freshwater)
nigiri.author: Tiffany D.
nigiri.review:
Cozy spot for fresh and high end nigiri!  

They described the servings and sake with such eloquence throughout the entire meal and dining experience.  No wonder why it is Michelin 2016 noteworthy. 

Their omakase set paired well with the individual sake served. 

My all time favorites: uni from Hokkaido, tuna belly and wagyu nigiri.  

What was unique: sazae (snail) that complimented well with the sweet sake, mini-sized what looked like a bento box of 3 servings that consisted of cod, okra and baby fish with seaweed, monkfish liver with redfish on top and anago nigiri (saltwater eel instead of unagi (freshwater) eel).  

Enjoyable dining over omakase with sake experience.  

"Okage sama," said my dining partner.  Thanks to you.  Gratitude and feeling appreciated at the finest.  I felt rewarded.

excerpts: You can order more nigiri that they have during your meal.
They will hand you another small paper menu that describes what nigiri they have for the day.
Personally, I'm not that big of a nigiri person.
After a while, the raw food was a bit overwhelming for me
but nonetheless I thought everything was perfect.
I just wish I had a better stomach for it.
My boyfriend is literally obsessed with nigiri so he was in heaven.
LOL.
All the seafood was so fresh, never had anything like it.
Their fried food.... ahhhh I'm crying a little just thinking about it!!
So unique in flavor.
The grilled fish with ginger on top was my favorite.
nigiri.author: Sarah L.
nigiri.review:
Is it worth the price? YES!! 

Reservations only. Plan ahead! 

INTERIOR: Small and cozy. Probably only seats about 20 at most. You have the choice to sit at the sushi bar where some chefs are making food, or one of the tables. (Must decide for reservation).

MENU: They hand you a small menu right when you are seated. It only has two pages that describe the 9 course and the 11 course meal. You can order more nigiri that they have during your meal. They will hand you another small paper menu that describes what nigiri they have for the day. 

MY EXPERIENCE: We came here for me and my boyfriends anniversary, and we were pleasantly surprised! Being a couple that usually eats fried food and boba ever other meal, this was a huge step up. LOL. We were at first a little intimidated, but our server described every course that they placed on our table. 
We chose the 11 course meal (130$ per person). Everything was AMAZING! Such great presentation and memorable taste. Their portions are definitely small, but everything tasted so fresh and great that we literally did not care because our experience made up for it. 
Personally, I'm not that big of a nigiri person. After a while, the raw food was a bit overwhelming for me but nonetheless I thought everything was perfect. I just wish I had a better stomach for it. My boyfriend is literally obsessed with nigiri so he was in heaven. LOL. All the seafood was so fresh, never had anything like it. 
Their fried food.... ahhhh I'm crying a little just thinking about it!! So unique in flavor. The grilled fish with ginger on top was my favorite. :') 

And their Ama Ebi fried head was THE best I have ever had. Worth every penny. 

CUSTOMER SERVICE: They were attentive, informative, and kind. Thank you to the chef who greeted us upon entry and exit! 

CONCLUSION: We will be back!! Would recommend to anyone who loves seafood.

excerpts: I'm used to omakase where it's mainly nigiri, however the omakase here is a bit different where they will bring out a lot of random dishes (kind of like kaiseki style), and serve the nigiri near the end.
I thought the nigiri pieces were extremely small, probably half of what it usually is compared to other omakase restaurants.
For the price point of $350 for 2 people (had a few beers as well)
we just didn't feel like it was worth the money.
Service was great and the quality of the fish was great, but it was overpriced for what it was.
nigiri.author: Angela K.
nigiri.review: Came here to celebrate my birthday with 3 other friends and were really excited to try this new restaurant out. I loved the ambiance of the place, it had a very clean rustic feel to it with all of the wooden accents. I'm used to omakase where it's mainly nigiri, however the omakase here is a bit different where they will bring out a lot of random dishes (kind of like kaiseki style), and serve the nigiri near the end. I thought the nigiri pieces were extremely small, probably half of what it usually is compared to other omakase restaurants. For the price point of $350 for 2 people (had a few beers as well) we just didn't feel like it was worth the money. Service was great and the quality of the fish was great, but it was overpriced for what it was.

excerpts: We were handed an à la carte menu towards the end of our meal, from which we each ordered 4 additional pieces of nigiri.
nigiri.author: Jennifer K.
nigiri.review:
For having maintained Michelin status for the past couple of years, Wako was disappointing.

My friend and I had the 9 course omakase, and while the fish was fresh, the portions were small and the flavors just weren't there. Additionally, the chefs weren't nearly as engaging as they were at KUSAKABE or jū-ni; service, otherwise, was perfectly fine.

ALSO, the website states, "Effective November 2016, A La Carte menu will no longer be available at the restaurant," but this is a LIE! We were handed an à la carte menu towards the end of our meal, from which we each ordered 4 additional pieces of nigiri.

Don't think I'll be back.

excerpts: We ordered the Nigiri Omakase for $100 each, which included some small plates, 12 pieces nigiri, miso soup, and dessert.

The sea cucumber stood out to me because it was the first time I've really enjoyed it, but everything was really good

For our nigiri, we were served (in order): Golden eye snapper, fire fish, striped jack, abalone, ink squid, blue fin tuna, mackerel, cold-smoked cherry salmon, sea urchin, blue fin tuna belly, sea eel, and Wagyu beef.
No soy sauce here unless you request it, and wasabi was minimal if not nonexistent on the nigiri.
BUT I didn't think any of the nigiri really needed either for the flavor, so that says something.
All the nigiri was great, but there were a few stand-outs.
My boyfriend's favorite was the cold-smoked cherry salmon, and my favorites were the sea urchin, tuna belly, and Wagyu beef.
So fresh and flavorful!
nigiri.author: Sara L.
nigiri.review:
My boyfriend and I managed to get a same-day reservation through OpenTable for our anniversary (though if you want to sit at the sushi bar, you'll have to make reservations over the phone more ahead of time).

We ordered the Nigiri Omakase for $100 each, which included some small plates, 12 pieces nigiri, miso soup, and dessert. 

Small plates: Calling them small bites instead of small plates would be more accurate. They're mostly amuse-bouche sized and included firefly squid, wagyu beef croquette, fried octopus leg, eel wrapped in egg, sea cucumber, fried tofu skin, and a few others I don't remember details of. The sea cucumber stood out to me because it was the first time I've really enjoyed it, but everything was really good

For our nigiri, we were served (in order): Golden eye snapper, fire fish, striped jack, abalone, ink squid, blue fin tuna, mackerel, cold-smoked cherry salmon, sea urchin, blue fin tuna belly, sea eel, and Wagyu beef.

Random note: No soy sauce here unless you request it, and wasabi was minimal if not nonexistent on the nigiri. BUT I didn't think any of the nigiri really needed either for the flavor, so that says something.

All the nigiri was great, but there were a few stand-outs. My boyfriend's favorite was the cold-smoked cherry salmon, and my favorites were the sea urchin, tuna belly, and Wagyu beef. So fresh and flavorful! Definitely the best I've ever had of each. 

A surprise near the end was complimentary tamago, which was the legit, homemade cakey/spongey kind with the perfect level of sweetness. 

Dessert was some kind of green tea mousse and a blueberry cheesecake mousse. Very light, but really good.

Minus 1 star for the service. It wasn't bad per say, but it was definitely not up to par with what I expect for the price range of the restaurant. We had to ask for water, ask for water refills, ask for ginger, etc. 

Overall, a great experience. I'd hope that if I came back, their service would be better.

excerpts: The food was great - especially the toro and uni, which were fantastic, but they forgot to serve us the last piece of nigiri sushi (we counted eleven pieces when there should have been twelve).
nigiri.author: Julian W.
nigiri.review:
The food was great - especially the toro and uni, which were fantastic, but they forgot to serve us the last piece of nigiri sushi (we counted eleven pieces when there should have been twelve). I hope they will not make this grave mistake in the future, since their food is so good that missing any of it is extremely disappointing. 

Additionally, they should serve a cup of hot tea at the end of the meal. It's a routine service for any kind of Japanese restaurant and consumes very little extra effort.

The service was friendly, although it felt a little rushed since they kept checking if we were done with our plates and bringing the next course with zero downtime.

With a couple minor tweaks to the service, this could be the perfect restaurant. Certainly the kitchen is on top of things!

excerpts:
Nigiri - 4 pieces consisting of red snapper, sea bass, salmon and scallop. 

Yakimono grilled dish - black cod with taro, ginko and baby turnip

Nigiri - 4 pieces consisting of wild yellowtail, stripped jack with dehydrated eggs and ginger, bonito, and tuna belly.

You can add on nigiris and we opted to add an abalone nigiri.
nigiri.author: Al L.
nigiri.review:
Walked by Wako many times and noticed that the restaurant was always full. It's been on my "to try" list and was happy to finally dine here for my birthday.  We were seated at a nice window table upon our arrival for our 5:30pm seating.  The restaurant is small and quaint with a sushi bar that seats about eight and six tables for 14 diners.  

The menu is simple with two omakase menu options, 9 course or 11 course.  After starting off with my Kirin, we were ready for our 9 course dining adventure.

Sakizuke starter - sesame tofu topped with uni.

Osechi appetizer - this was a special Japanese appetizer for the New Year. It was a beautiful plated dish consisting of seven items - Enoki mushrooms, salmon roe and dichon, sweet black beans with gold flakes, eel in egg, potato with Wagyu filling, baby anchovies and chestnut over sweet potato

Otsukuri sashimi - a beautiful plated dish of blue fin tuna topped with dried egg shavings and amberjack with yuzu shavings.

Mushimono steamed - a bowl of bonito kelp broth with fish cake, mochi, chicken ball, shitake and dichon. 

Nigiri - 4 pieces consisting of red snapper, sea bass, salmon and scallop. 

Yakimono grilled dish - black cod with taro, ginko and baby turnip

Nigiri - 4 pieces consisting of wild yellowtail, stripped jack with dehydrated eggs and ginger, bonito, and tuna belly.

You can add on nigiris and we opted to add an abalone nigiri. It consisted of three pieces of abalone topped with dehydrated eggs on top of kelp rice. 

Tome-wan - choice of white or red miso soup

Dessert - choice of lychee champagne cake or chestnut mousse cake

Meal was finished with Mignardises - two pieces of chocolate. 

Wow! What a dining experience! The dishes were like beautiful artwork that were amazingly delicious. Interesting and unique food. Service was friendly and attentive. For an amazing omakase, check out Wako!

excerpts: it was not all nigiri besides the egg dessert which is what I was expecting because that's how it was at Jiro.
At one end I'm glad because it had us try things that we normally wouldn't ever order ourselves,
but on the other end of the spectrum I wish we had more nigiri because that's the best!
nigiri.author: Annissa H.
nigiri.review:
Brought the hubs here for his birthday since he was dyin for omasake in the states. We love sushi but never had omasake for an unknown reason. While in Japan we got to eat a Jiro and since then we were wanting to have omasake here to see and compare but never really got a chance til now.

I made reservations online because I thought eating at a table would be more intimate for his birthday, plus we have sat at the bar at Jiro and seen it all (you need to call in and request bar seating).I honestly thought sitting at the bar here would be as intense as Jiro but from what I saw it didn't seem like it at all. If you've seen the Jiro documentary you can understand why you would feel nervous. However it wasn't until we got there is when I became aware that the main sushi master (is there a formal term for this?) makes the dishes for the people at the bar and his apprentices are the ones who makes the dishes for those at tables.. shucks!

The main difference is that here at Wako the courses included a soba noodle soup, shredded tuna, lotus chips, etc. it was not all nigiri besides the egg dessert which is what I was expecting because that's how it was at Jiro. At one end I'm glad because it had us try things that we normally wouldn't ever order ourselves,  but on the other end of the spectrum I wish we had more nigiri because that's the best!

This was our first time trying the cod milt and oh my goodness was it so f*cking delicious. We didn't even know what it was until we finished it and we googled it and thought what the hell.. damn that was delicious though, I want some more!

All in all it was good and a fun dinner. Go early to find parking and get some yummy desserts at Schuberts to kill time before your reservation :)

excerpts: Glad we did because as other reviewers mentioned, you do seem to get better fish and of course more since it's 12 pieces of nigiri.
but I did take pictures of each nigiri.
Some of my favs were the Otoro (omg melts in your mouth, I had to have a moment where I just closed my eyes and tuned out the world), the cherry blossom salmon, the wagyu beef (never ate raw before
but it's such high grade
it's like sushi) and
the sea eel (not like what you typically expect at all.
Super soft and buttery, not fishy like eel is).
For the starter, there was ice fish which I wasn't a big fan of because of how strange it looked (clear transparent fish with little eyes) and a bit fishy but good to try.
There was also a box of all these unique things like squid, bamboo, mini potato ball, and clam.
nigiri.author: Melissa L.
nigiri.review:
Came here to celebrate the bf's bday and glad we did. I made reservations a few weeks prior to make sure we got to sit at the bar. There's only about 10 seats and they only open 530-10pm therefore plan in advance. 

My first time doing Omakase but my bf has had pretty authentic experiences in Japan. I'm glad it lived up to his standards. There were 2 price points, we opted for the $100 set vs the $70ish one. Glad we did because as other reviewers mentioned, you do seem to get better fish and of course more since it's 12 pieces of nigiri. 

So many courses it was hard to keep track but I did take pictures of each nigiri. Some of my favs were the Otoro (omg melts in your mouth, I had to have a moment where I just closed my eyes and tuned out the world), the cherry blossom salmon, the wagyu beef (never ate raw before but it's such high grade it's like sushi) and the sea eel (not like what you typically expect at all. Super soft and buttery, not fishy like eel is). For the starter, there was ice fish which I wasn't a big fan of because of how strange it looked (clear transparent fish with little eyes) and a bit fishy but good to try. There was also a box of all these unique things like squid, bamboo, mini potato ball, and clam. Overall experience was great, sushi chef was very attentive and friendly, we had some good conversations. 

Great place to have sushi. Not a place you go to all the time but good especially if you're looking to celebrate something special or want to experience a Michelin star restaurant!

excerpts: Presentation was appealing and the effort they put into each nigiri was up there, but the flavors were just MIA.
Opted for the $100/pp omakase which came with a few small plates (more like tiny), 12 pc nigiri, miso soup, and dessert.
Nothing at all stood out for me the entire meal.
I couldn't even get myself to finish the miso soup OR dessert as it was just not that appetizing enough.
Don't get me wrong, it wasn't a bad meal, but was expecting so much for a michelin star restaurant.
Everything was just OK.
Was it worth the price?
Yes, I think so.
Would I come back again?
nigiri.author: Anna M.
nigiri.review:
Made reservations to sit at the sushi bar expecting a mind-blowing experience.

Nope.

Sighduck... was so excited to try this place because I've heard nothing but GREAT things, but sad to say the meal was only mediocre. Presentation was appealing and the effort they put into each nigiri was up there, but the flavors were just MIA. Chefs really do focus more on technique rather than taste.

Opted for the $100/pp omakase which came with a few small plates (more like tiny), 12 pc nigiri, miso soup, and dessert. Nothing at all stood out for me the entire meal. I couldn't even get myself to finish the miso soup OR dessert as it was just not that appetizing enough. Don't get me wrong, it wasn't a bad meal, but was expecting so much for a michelin star restaurant. Everything was just OK. Was it worth the price? Yes, I think so. Would I come back again? Nope.

Service on the other hand, was top notch.

Tip: Wear nothing... because it's HOT A F up in this joint! I was lightheaded the entire meal.

excerpts: The bar is the place to be, you can watch as the chef warms the rice and fish to prep your nigiri so that the fish fat just melts in your mouth.
nigiri.author: Maymie C.
nigiri.review:
Firstly, don't get omakase if you're looking for " regular Wednesday night grab some sushi type sushi places"...  you WILL be disappointed. In fact, I'M offended on behalf of the restaurant!! Lol. 

We came here because bf and I were craving good omakase after coming back from Japan. This was definitely comparable in quality and price. The bar is the place to be, you can watch as the chef warms the rice and fish to prep your nigiri so that the fish fat just melts in your mouth. Here's a pro-tip: eat the fish as soon as the chef plops it in front of you to get the full flavor of the fish fat.

Some variety of fish I hadn't tried before, ever try parrot fish or cured barracuda? Pretty damn delicious. They really got the gastronomy right on  point so that the umami really pops. My favorite were the bonito, seared scallop, and of coooourse the o-toro topped with sturgeon caviar and gold flakes (WTF I'm eating gold). 

I'm not bougie, but I sure can appreciate some good AF omakase. 

PS the tamago was delicious, no one ever remembers to give love to the decadent seafood cake.

excerpts: The dinner consists of different cooked items and Nigiri.
I cannot even begin to commend on how delicious everything tasted.
I've never had Nigiri without soy sauce so
at first I was a little hesitant but that hesitation was out the door within seconds as soon as I had my first Nigiri of the night.
The fish was so fresh and delicious it melted in our mouth like butter!
We savored every single bite in our mouth.
nigiri.author: Betty L.
nigiri.review:
I took my boyfriend here to celebrate his birthday and it was the best decision ever! We sat at the bar, ordered the 11 course Omakase dinner $130/person and it was well worth every dollar. The dinner consists of different cooked items and Nigiri. I cannot even begin to commend on how delicious everything tasted. I've never had Nigiri without soy sauce so at first I was a little hesitant but that hesitation was out the door within seconds as soon as I had my first Nigiri of the night. The fish was so fresh and delicious it melted in our mouth like butter! We savored every single bite in our mouth. Sashimi will never taste the same after our experience at Wako.

The place is small but very intimate and quiet. The decor is really nice and comforting. The staff is very friendly. Sitting in front of the chef definitely changed the whole experience and would recommend sitting at the bar. I cannot wait to be back again. This entire experience was phenomenal and hands down the food is AMAZING! HIGHLY RECOMMEND!

excerpts: The fish there is super fresh, nigiri doesn't have too much rice and is not over seasoned.
nigiri.author: Rohenne L.
nigiri.review:
Best Omakase in SF! Love it and will be back soon.

Small and cozy, make sure you sit by the bar for omakase. The chef - Tomo - is awesome! He's not only very detail oriented and makes sure each piece you're having is great but also great sense of humor.

The fish there is super fresh, nigiri doesn't have too much rice and is not over seasoned. This place is similar to authentic Japanese sushi where you don't need to dip it in soy sauce, it comes sauced and you just pick it up with you hand and put it in your mouth.

Very reasonable price! $100/person for a lot of food. We got an extra small plate of baby squids, which was in season!(we're so lucky). 

My favorite piece of the night was the blue fin tuna cheek seared slightly with caviar on top. Usually, I don't like caviar so was a bit unsure if is like this piece but as I put it in my mouth, the flavors just blended perfectly. 

I can't wait to come back again. :)

excerpts: We both got the omakase nigiri sets.
The omakase nigiri set comes with small plates, 12 pieces of nigiri, soup, and dessert.
The small plates were exceptional and varied.
There was a fresh persimmon salad that was inside a hollowed out persimmon, fresh tuna, croquette and other bite size appetizers.
The omakase nigiri set comes with small plates, 12 pieces of nigiri, soup, and dessert.
The small plates were exceptional and varied.
There was a fresh persimmon salad that was inside a hollowed out persimmon, fresh tuna, croquette and other bite size appetizers.
All of them were great but the main attraction was of course the nigiri.
nigiri.author: Jocelyn K.
nigiri.review:
Wako is one of the best sushi places I have ever been to and was an absolutely delightful dining experience. I came here with my friend on a Tuesday night and we had reservations at the bar. We both got the omakase nigiri sets.

FOOD: The omakase nigiri set comes with small plates, 12 pieces of nigiri, soup, and dessert. The small plates were exceptional and varied. There was a fresh persimmon salad that was inside a hollowed out persimmon, fresh tuna, croquette and other bite size appetizers. All of them were great but the main attraction was of course the nigiri. 

This sushi was the best I have ever had. I was sick with the FLU and super meh feeling and this STILL tasted amazing. First, the sushi rice was actually sushi rice which is already a huge plus compared to most places. It was soft and pillowy. What was even better was that the rice wasn't just sweet but also had a bit of saltiness with it.

All of the fish was exceptionally fresh and melt in your mouth. The fish came from all over the world and were definitely higher quality. Since the chef chooses and makes each piece individually when you are ready, I ended up eating many uncommon fishes such as abalone and clam. Surprisingly, they were amazing! My favorites were the otoro and yellow tail belly but I even loved the Uni which is normally dislike! 

The miso soup and dessert were fine. A great end to the meal but nothing super amazing.

EXPERIENCE/ATMOSPHERE: Sitting at the counter is great because you get to see the chefs work and they are very attentive in carefully spacing out your meal. They are happy to answer any questions to have about the fish. There is plenty of time to leisurely chat with your dining partner so make sure you like each other's company!

The restaurant itself is very intimate and small which I think allows you to really get the whole experience of enjoying the preparation. However, it would not be suitable for a big party. 

There were two chefs who both were Japanese. They seemed like they were trained in Japan and very passionate about making their food taste great but also look beautiful. Furthermore, the chefs were very kind and engaging!

LOCATION: This place is located on clement in the Richmond. There didn't seem to be any parking issues when we went.

PRICE: The particular omakase I got was $100 per person which is quite pricy. An individual piece of sushi ranged from $6-8 per piece. Therefore, this place isn't cheap. However is it worth the price? If you are just looking to stuff your face with sushi then maybe not. However, if you are looking for a complete experience with sushi quality above most restaurants, even those on Japan, then I would really recommend checking Wako out. Again I was sick and this place was still enjoyable and was the best sushi I have ever had!!! I definitely would go back again!

FINAL THOUGHTS: I see some complaints about the size of this sushi compared to other places in japantown or Irving. Personally, I do not think this is comparable to those places. Although the pieces are smaller and more expensive, the quality is much better (and I say this as someone who loves sushi from Irving and jtown.) This sushi melts in your mouth and taste so fresh, the quality is definitely a few grades above. Also, it is authentic compared to the places I have been in Japan. Yes there are some places in Japan that have cheaper and bigger sushi like the quality in your run in the mill sushi places in sunset but there is also higher end sushi like that found in Wako. If you are willing to spend more for amazing sushi then I would really recommend trying out Wako. Its Michelin star was well deserved!

excerpts: We both ordered the $100 12 pieces nigiri option, which also came with a few hot dishes as well.
I don't think I've ever exclaimed "omg" after taking a bite of anything, but this happened a few times that night.
Our favorites were the filefish with filefish liver on top, smoked cherry salmon, blue fin tuna, and wagyu beef.
The marinade and toppings on those were minimal but the flavor and texture combined were amazing.
Everything was great, but we both couldn't stop talking about those four for awhile.
Watching the chefs prepare the nigiri was a treat as well as you can see all the effort that is put into  each piece.
The nigiri were the highlights
so I'm glad I did not choose the cheaper omakase option which would have featured less nigiri.
For the price, it was definitely worth it.
I was honestly not expecting that much food.
nigiri.author: Linh H.
nigiri.review:
I wanted to treat the bf out and decided on omakase because both of us has never had that before. I did a search around the city and figured I might as well go for a place that has a Michelin star. I had made a reservation online and decided to call in later that evening to try to get the sushi bar seating. It worked out well as they were able to accommodate us at the sushi bar seating at an even better reservation time. He changed it on open table for me as well.

We both ordered the $100 12 pieces nigiri option, which also came with a few hot dishes as well. I don't think I've ever exclaimed "omg" after taking a bite of anything, but this happened a few times that night. Our favorites were the filefish with filefish liver on top, smoked cherry salmon, blue fin tuna, and wagyu beef. The marinade and toppings on those were minimal but the flavor and texture combined were amazing. Everything was great, but we both couldn't stop talking about those four for awhile. The cool thing was that the chef also showed us the certification on the wagyu beef to show authentication. 

Watching the chefs prepare the nigiri was a treat as well as you can see all the effort that is put into  each piece. He also checks on you to see how they taste, of course my response was always a succession of nods and exclamation of how good it tasted, which probably made me look like a bobbling idiot. 

I don't think I was a big fan of the hot dishes except for maybe 2, one being this warm savory egg custard dish that had a surprise in every bite. It was literally something different each time I went in. The nigiri were the highlights so I'm glad I did not choose the cheaper omakase option which would have featured less nigiri. For the price, it was definitely worth it. I was honestly not expecting that much food.

excerpts: Tried the $100/pp nigiri omakase menu and the food was good, but lacks the wow factor of a Michelin star restaurant.
I also wished the sauces were more different between the different fishes to distinguish each nigiri piece from the other.
Another miss was the ratio between the fish and the rice for the nigiri pieces.
The rice was the right size, but the slices of fish were a lot smaller (barely covering the rice) even for Edo-style sushi.
nigiri.author: Jessica K.
nigiri.review:
Tried the $100/pp nigiri omakase menu and the food was good, but lacks the wow factor of a Michelin star restaurant.

All of the fishes were fresh, but most came with sauces that overpowered the original flavor and sweetness of the fishes. I also wished the sauces were more different between the different fishes to distinguish each nigiri piece from the other. 

Another miss was the ratio between the fish and the rice for the nigiri pieces. The rice was the right size, but the slices of fish were a lot smaller (barely covering the rice) even for Edo-style sushi. Portion size was way off and be forewarned that you may leave feeling a little hungry after the meal.

Knifing skills also needs some work. The otoro was not cut properly because there was a stubborn muscle/vein right in the middle that neither my date or I can bite off. This is a novice mistake that you would not see at Kusakabe or at Uni Sushi (before the chef retired).

Oh, and also docking a star for lackluster service.

In summary, if you are looking for a traditional sushi restaurant away from FiDi, Wako may be an option. However, if you are looking for authentic and delicious Japanese cuisine, try Kappou Gomi instead.

excerpts: Some of the really standout nigiri are the applewood smoked salmon, barracuda, red snapper, blue fin tuna, wagyu -- an all time favorite sea eel.
The monkfish liver and the uni dishes are awesome as well.
Wako, woo!!
nigiri.author: DeAnna C.
nigiri.review:
Have eaten here twice now - once before the Michelin star and then after. 

Overall this place is great! The omakase is an amazing experience from the quality and thoughtfulness of each dish to the attentive service from the wait staff. Some of the really standout nigiri are the applewood smoked salmon, barracuda, red snapper, blue fin tuna, wagyu -- an all time favorite sea eel. The monkfish liver and the uni dishes are awesome as well. Wako, woo!!

excerpts: 8-piece nigiri, miso soup and dessert.
Of the nigiri I thought that the weakest ones were the barracuda, striped jack and the snow crab with crab butter.
nigiri.author: Sam L.
nigiri.review:
OH-MY-GOSH-YEAH!!!

This is what I like to exclaim every time I have delicious OMAKASE. Wako's Omakase is no exception. This place is slowly becoming my location for my sushi fix in SF and celebration destination. My wife surprised me with birthday reservations for a Sunday at 6pm and I was excited when the GPS led me in front of Wako. We came here about 4 months ago closer to the time Wako opened up and the experience was equally excellent. 

Wako offers one of the best Omakase offerings in SF and at $76, I think they provide a fairly good value for what you get. Their food is a fusion of fresh Californian ingredients in the Japanese tradition. So what do you get exactly?! You get a delicious 7 course omakase meal in the following order:

A starter, sashimi course, grilled course, warm course, tempura course, 8-piece nigiri, miso soup and dessert.

With Sade playing in the background, all the couples dining last night were in for a nice romantic setting....and probably some love-making afterwards.

Of the nigiri I thought that the weakest ones were the barracuda, striped jack and the snow crab with crab butter. Try to eat those first to get them out of the way.

Chinook salmon was just ok that day...not as buttery as the last time.
The yellowtail was orgasmic
The Spanish mackerel was delish
The O-Toro...o....ooooo....ooooo my gosh yeah! 

Lessons learned this time around: 
1. Make reservations!
2. EAT AT THE SUSHI BAR
3. Don't forget to order the hamachi if you don't get some with the omakase...

Overall, I appreciate all the attention to detail from the handmade menus, the wood paneled walls, the homemade sesame seed tofu and post-meal chocolates, the cool tea cups, the serene and clean bathroom, and of course...the delicious food. I can't wait till our next celebration to return here!

excerpts: Praise the lawwwwd for the titillating Omakase Nigiri I had at Wako last night.
Every single piece of fish was exceptional.
Although I normally consider anago to be very mediocre, this version was bomb diggity.
The uni, o-toro and wagyu were so decadent that we had to get seconds of each.
The meal, which included an appetizer trio, 18 pieces of nigiri (10 pieces minimum), tamago and soup, plus a bottle of sake split between three people came out to about $170 per person pre-tip.
nigiri.author: Suany W.
nigiri.review:
Praise the lawwwwd for the titillating Omakase Nigiri I had at Wako last night. Every single piece of fish was exceptional. Although I normally consider anago to be very mediocre, this version was bomb diggity. The uni, o-toro and wagyu were so decadent that we had to get seconds of each. Heavenly on the lips, diabolical on the hips. 

The meal, which included an appetizer trio, 18 pieces of nigiri (10 pieces minimum), tamago and soup, plus a bottle of sake split between three people came out to about $170 per person pre-tip. 

Here's a list of all the fish I sampled last night, in case you give a shit:

Rosy sea bass
Halibut
Cuttle fish
Giant clam
Abalone 
Striped jack
Chinook king salmon
Barracuda 
Spanish mackerel 
Gizzard shad
Seared scallop
Uni 
O-toro
Anago
Wagyu

excerpts: Even though I thought the chef put too much wasabi on the nigiri, the selection of fish was fresh and I thought the rice was perfectly seasoned on the nigiri.

Larger portions of fish, extra gold leaf and caviar, and what really pissed me off, the option to order extra items a la carte at the end of the nigiri service that wasn't offered to anybody else except your regulars.
To not even offer the option to order more nigiri to your other customers as we watch you lavish your regulars with extra pieces of uni, toro, and wagyu is completely UNACCEPTABLE.
It's a NUMBERS game.
If 75% of your restaurant are first-timers and their initial feel of your restaurant is one of favoritism and inequality, then you've alienated and lost a substantial customer base.
You can make your regulars feel special and cared while at the same time not alienating your new customers.
My boyfriend and I would have gladly ordered extra pieces, which in turn means more profit for you.
nigiri.author: Kaisi G.
nigiri.review:
Sigh. I had such high hopes for you Wako. As an avid omakase frequenter in the city, I was thrilled to finally get a reservation for you as you are right by my house and your prices are decent considering other prices for omakase in SF. 

And I will say the service by your wait staff was great, the interior decor was charming and welcoming, and the sake pairing we had with our meal was fantastic. Even though I thought the chef put too much wasabi on the nigiri, the selection of fish was fresh and I thought the rice was perfectly seasoned on the nigiri. The snow crab chawanmushi was also one of the best I've ever had. 

HOWEVER, I did not appreciate being treated like I was inferior to your regulars. You know it's bad when I've had six glasses of sake and I immediately rush home to write this review because that's how upset I am. It's freaking 10:45pm on a Tuesday and it's Valentine's Day and I'm sitting here typing away like a madwoman. 

For a 10-seater sushi bar, it's inevitable that you see how your fellow diners are treated. We had the misfortune to be seated tonight next to some of your regulars. Right away they were greeted and treated differently by the chef and the staff. That's fine - our service and treatment were great and it's understandable that a restaurant would treat its regulars differently because hello they're regulars - the special treatment is probably in part what keeps them coming back. Who doesn't like feeling special?

However, as the night progressed, I started seeing notable differences between the regulars and the rest of the customers. Larger portions of fish, extra gold leaf and caviar, and what really pissed me off, the option to order extra items a la carte at the end of the nigiri service that wasn't offered to anybody else except your regulars. 

To not even offer the option to order more nigiri to your other customers as we watch you lavish your regulars with extra pieces of uni, toro, and wagyu is completely UNACCEPTABLE. It's a NUMBERS game. If 75% of your restaurant are first-timers and their initial feel of your restaurant is one of favoritism and inequality, then you've alienated and lost a substantial customer base. You can make your regulars feel special and cared while at the same time not alienating your new customers. My boyfriend and I would have gladly ordered extra pieces, which in turn means more profit for you. By not even offering the option to your other customers LITERALLY means you are turning away money. 

When I'm paying over $250/pp and the feeling I walk away from your restaurant is one of disrespect, there is a serious problem. Wako, you've lost my business and what's even more sad, you've completely neglected what true sushi-yas are all about - that feeling of welcome, of strangers coming together into your home and sharing that warm feeling of delicious food and the love and care you've put into making it. I'm truly disappointed by this experience and am so mad at myself for choosing you to celebrate a special occasion.

excerpts:
) Nigiri round 1 (4 pieces)
6)
Nigiri round 2 (4 pieces)
We were brought 8 pieces of chef's choice as well as presented with a menu to order additional individual pieces.
They were all delicious and with great rice to fish ratio.
The rice had a really good consistency and texture.
Flavoring for each piece was done by the chef and generally was great.
The wasabi was a little bit heavy on maybe 1 or 2 of the pieces though (on the salmon nigiri, I teared up a bit and trust me
I love wasabi).
We also ordered the wagyu nigiri as recommended by our friend and this piece was the absolutely most delicious thing I've ever taste.
I HIGHLY RECOMMEND the wagyu nigiri!!!
Hands down, our favorite chosen by the chef was the scallop nigiri, which I also recommend.
nigiri.author: Vivian L.
nigiri.review:
My boyfriend and I were able to make a last minute reservation for the next night to celebrate a special occasion, but granted this was on Tuesday night. Unfortunately we were unable to reserve seats at the bar for the full experience, but nonetheless we both found Wako amazing. 

The setup of the restaurant was as expected of a high-end sushi restaurant--intimate, clean, and modestly decorated. The noise level was minimal and perfect for conversation, and for a high-end restaurant, the atmosphere was not overwhelming or intimidating. 

We chose the $92 9-course meal and did not get the sake pairing. Sitting away from the bar, the courses were brought out and explained by a waitress. Regarding the food, this was both our first omakase experience and it was simply amazing! The food and presentation were mind-blowing definitely exemplified the chef's creativity and skill. 

The service was okay. Our food was brought out in a very timely manner, but we did have to prompt our waitress a few times for more tea as we ran out of a few times. It was also hard to hear the waitress at times (warning: courses may be inaccurate or missing details, I stopped asking her to repeat herself after the first few times).

The courses:
1) Seaweed with vinaigrette
Refreshing "shot" of seaweed to start the meal.

2) Assorted appetizers
4 small appetizers bites with very cute presentation. We really liked the eggplant and the fish skewer. The other 2 were oyster and veggies that were okay.

3) Sashimi
Small bowl with 2 types of sashimi was perfect. Only wish we were given more sashimi!

4) Potato and fish soup
This was my least favorite course. The fish had little pieces of bones in it that I assume was intended to be chew-able, but I personally was not a fan of the little bones. I had one bone (or fish scale?) that surprised me with the first bite. The soup still tasted great and my boyfriend had no complaints about the fish bones and loved it.

5) Nigiri round 1 (4 pieces)
6) Nigiri round 2 (4 pieces)
We were brought 8 pieces of chef's choice as well as presented with a menu to order additional individual pieces. They were all delicious and with great rice to fish ratio. The rice had a really good consistency and texture. Flavoring for each piece was done by the chef and generally was great. The wasabi was a little bit heavy on maybe 1 or 2 of the pieces though (on the salmon nigiri, I teared up a bit and trust me I love wasabi). 
We also ordered the wagyu nigiri as recommended by our friend and this piece was the absolutely most delicious thing I've ever taste. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND the wagyu nigiri!!! Hands down, our favorite chosen by the chef was the scallop nigiri, which I also recommend.

7) Mackerel with daikon
Personally I had some reservation with this dish due to the tiny fish bones in it, but besides the bones everything was amazingly delicious. Presentation was very nice.

8) Miso soup (option of red or white)
We both chose red miso as the waitress describe this as "richer". Loved it.

9) Dessert (option of persimmon or strawberry lychee pudding) 
We got one of each types of pudding. Overall they were not that memorable, but we still finished both cleanly.

Overall this was a phenomenal first omakase experience. The food was excellent and my boyfriend and I were both very happy and satisfied by the end.

excerpts:
Mackerel and Amber Jack nigiri: 
A.
I never knew raw mackerel tastes that good! 
With the special house sauce the chef put on both of these fish, my mouth was very satisfied.
(http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=_bkCDlfpBupJy5DTUYrVtg&userid=Juh-g9sATZppHvMmNmHfFw)

#6th course
Salmon and Spanish Mackerel Nigiri: A.
Abalone nigiri: A+.
I was blown away by this. 
Super fresh abalone, super nice texture and again the house sauce really enhanced the overall feeling of the nigiri. 
Wow.... very good.
Ayu fish nigiri: 
B+.
Don't get me wrong, this dish would probably receive an A in other typical sushi restaurant but the standard is too high here. 
(http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=gebJHt2r-YxJzkWWNKMW9Q&userid=Juh-g9sATZppHvMmNmHfFw)

#9th course
Snow Crab nigiri and Tuna Belly nigiri: A+.
nigiri.author: Simon C.
nigiri.review:
Let's face it. Omakase is expensive. I really don't want to spend a lot of money on an unsatisfied Omakase experience and so I always do a lot of research before trying out Omakase from a restaurant. Based on fellow Yelpers reviews, Wako sounds like a solid choice. Went and ate, did not disappoint a single bit.

Made a reservation for three for a Sunday dinner at 8:30pm. Sat down and went straight for the Omakase 7-course. (The dishes didn't come in exactly 7-course style - I guess it has to do with chef's arrangements about what to eat first, what to follow, etc)

#1st course
Cherry Blossom Shrimp Seaweed Salad, plus some small fish/scallop: A.
One main reason I am giving it an A for these slightly ordinary dishes is due to the fact that the presentation was super nice. (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Hf2ofAbVdZ0F6soFHvXKtw&userid=Juh-g9sATZppHvMmNmHfFw) Especially that small pea plus scallop ball thing... very cute and you can tell how much time the chef put into making this omakase a perfect experience. The choices of those ingredients made this course a very nice start of the dinner.

#2nd course
Blue Fin Tuna and Sea Bass Sashimi: A-.
This was probably the best blue fin tuna I have ever had. Very fresh, and definitely tasted like some premium fish. The sea bass was very good too. These two kinds of fish are not my favorite so I might be a little biased here but even so I enjoyed the freshness a lot.
(http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=CxIYljpHTRWnInvXmHTFcQ&userid=Juh-g9sATZppHvMmNmHfFw)

#3rd course
Red Snapper, Lotus Root and Braised Seaweed: A.
The red snapper was slightly grilled - the time and temperature must have been controlled very well, which allowed the snapper to keep its juice inside the meat while its slightly crispy on the outside. Brilliant.
(http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=KXiIVnQGP2YpV1DmunNlSQ&userid=Juh-g9sATZppHvMmNmHfFw)

#4th course
Tempura, Ginger Marinated Tomato, and Green Tea Soba etc: A.
Another presentation-win here. Those little tempura pieces were perfectly fried. Green Tea Soba was very refreshing after the grilled red snapper dish, and matched the tempura super well.
(http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=7YDvrNnKM1goSEPYULHjAw&userid=Juh-g9sATZppHvMmNmHfFw)

#5th course
Mackerel and Amber Jack nigiri: A.
I never knew raw mackerel tastes that good! With the special house sauce the chef put on both of these fish, my mouth was very satisfied.
(http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=_bkCDlfpBupJy5DTUYrVtg&userid=Juh-g9sATZppHvMmNmHfFw)

#6th course
Salmon and Spanish Mackerel Nigiri: A.
Keeping it up the high bar! Both were very fresh of course. Very heavy salmon taste which you can never find from local Gaijin sushi joints.
(http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=qdtri84cFgMCKffuKDLBbQ&userid=Juh-g9sATZppHvMmNmHfFw)

#7th course
Abalone nigiri: A+.
I was blown away by this. Super fresh abalone, super nice texture and again the house sauce really enhanced the overall feeling of the nigiri. Wow.... very good.
(http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=AiEw225cNY25wma1q1z7lA&userid=Juh-g9sATZppHvMmNmHfFw)

#8th course
Ayu fish nigiri: B+.
Don't get me wrong, this dish would probably receive an A in other typical sushi restaurant but the standard is too high here. 
(http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=gebJHt2r-YxJzkWWNKMW9Q&userid=Juh-g9sATZppHvMmNmHfFw)

#9th course
Snow Crab nigiri and Tuna Belly nigiri: A+.
Another mind-blowing dish. The tuna belly was super, SUPER good. Completely feeling the fat. Snow crab was handled very nicely - didn't have the sea salt water taste whatsoever but with heavy, HEAVT crab smell and taste to it.
(http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=2SN8vfWMUkYXiNKPThjJGw&userid=Juh-g9sATZppHvMmNmHfFw)

#10th course
Red Miso Soup: A-.
Pretty good. One of the friends got regular miso and he tried ours, and said he regretted not getting red type instead. It's got a pretty unique flavor in it in a good way.
(http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=RKCUJUmJ1GVz1Pb__g6BjA&userid=Juh-g9sATZppHvMmNmHfFw)

#11th course
Almond Ginger dessert: A.
Even the dessert received tons of attention! Looks like a 6-star hotel high-tea dessert, this almond ginger pudding-sort-of dish was a nice way to close the dinner. Heavy almond and ginger taste. With all the kiwi and berries added, very enjoyable.
(http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=K0hc8lccRf35Naw94YmGaQ&userid=Juh-g9sATZppHvMmNmHfFw)

With all of the above, 3 bottles of beer, and 2 bottles of sake, it came out ~$120/person out of the door. This price tag could easily be 1.5x elsewhere with this quality and quantity of food.

I love Wako. There will definitely be a second time, or even third, fourth, etc.. No doubt.

excerpts: My mom and I both ordered the 7 course omakase for $82 - the omakase nigiri for$100 would have been overkill - though
, the 7 course didn't come with the wagyu onigiri
nigiri.author: Annie L.
nigiri.review:
Given Wako has a Michelin star, I was not impressed.. maybe my standards were too high? I made reservations for Mother's day a couple days beforehand and was glad I did - the restaurant only has 4-5 tables and bar seating. I would have preferred sitting at the bar but they only had a 5:30 reservation for table so I took that one instead. They do take down a credit card number in case you flake - so make sure you are going to go before you make the reservation. 

Parking in the Richmond district is always tough so make sure to come early - we were stuck in SF traffic and called to let them know we were running a bit late. The restaurant was very gracious and understood but wanted us to keep in mind that the next table seating was at 7:15. Anyways, we actually arrived on time so it was fine. 

My mom and I both ordered the 7 course omakase for $82 - the omakase nigiri for$100 would have been overkill - though, the 7 course didn't come with the wagyu onigiri so I was a bit bummed - should have done better research beforehand. 

1) The first hot dish was my favorite. There were five items - fried squid and tuna with caviar were my two favorite items. This dish comes out shaped like art. 
2) Sashimi plate - not super fresh... I've had better. 
3) Vegetable dish - they do have fava beans - which are a favorite of mine. 
4) Tempura - fish cake tempura, tomato, and green beans. I like fish cake...but that was about it for this dish. 
5)  Onigiri - the squid and toro onigiri taste the best. Drooooool. The others are average. They do tell you that the sauce is already drizzled on the fish so no sauce is given. Although I do like the high grade ginger they gave us. 
6) Hamachi dumplings - this was an extra dish I ordered - very average and fishy, I was expecting something else.. these were more hamachi balls rather than dumplings. 
7) I was SUPER excited for the dessert given all the reviews - they had green tea mousse w/ a blackberry on top... unfortunately I'm allergic to blackberry so I asked if there were any substitutes.. none :( The desserts were all premade. 

Hmmm, I noticed a lot of people said they prefer Wako to Kusakabe but I liked Kusakabe a looot more and the service was much better. Oh well, at least I tried it and could compare the two.

excerpts: The best part was obviously the sashimi/ nigiri portion.
The Chu toro and Uni were amazing to me!
The Uni was the  right consistency with no fishy smell or taste which is good.
I've had some Uni where it tastes extremely fishy
and it was gross.
But this Uni was good!
I don't remember all the other fishes
nigiri.author: Stella J.
nigiri.review:
I would have to say this is a long overdue review. This is definitely one of the newer omakase places but it's still pretty decent for being in the Richmond district. 

My boyfriend and I came here almost a year ago to try the omakase and we chose the 7 course omakase I believe. 

We started off with some warm dishes such as tofu and some other dishes that were standard. The best part was obviously the sashimi/ nigiri portion. The Chu toro and Uni were amazing to me! The Uni was the  right consistency with no fishy smell or taste which is good. I've had some Uni where it tastes extremely fishy and it was gross. But this Uni was good! I don't remember all the other fishes but I do remember that they were decent and not bad at all. 

Another highlight was the dessert! It was a peach panna cotta, it had a strong peach taste which was not too sweet but delicious! It was the perfect ending to a good meal. 

I would definitely come back again to try omakase to see what other new fishes are on the menu.

excerpts: I found them to be just average, and would have enjoyed the meal more if I had just done the nigiri omakase.
Now on to the nigiri.
We were served atka mackeral, ink squid, chinook king salmon, scallop, blue fin tuna in a jalapeno soy marinade, uni, toro, sea eel, and tamago.
nigiri.author: Noelle H.
nigiri.review:
We sat at the sushi bar and we each got the 7 course meal.

The first course were several small bites that included a seaweed salad, firefly squid, fried scallop, egg cake, and house made tofu.  Decent, but nothing incredible.  The second course was tuna and halibut sashimi. Very fresh and tender.  The third course was a cooked fish that was just a tad overdone to my liking.  Flavors were okay.  The fourth course was fried baby fish with seaweed. This was my least favorite course. The fried fish had a strong off putting flavor. Tempura was decent, but again not mind blowing.  Overall, I was unimpressed with the warm dishes we received. I found them to be just average, and would have enjoyed the meal more if I had just done the nigiri omakase. 

Now on to the nigiri. We were served atka mackeral, ink squid, chinook king salmon, scallop, blue fin tuna in a jalapeno soy marinade, uni, toro, sea eel, and tamago. We ordered blue shrimp and snow crab in addition to the pieces we received. 

Each piece was delectable and melt-in-your-mouth fantastic. My favorites have to be the scallop, uni, toro and sea eel. Ahh, and the tamago is a MUST. The fluffiest I've ever had. It tasted like pound cake, especially since its served warm. 

We were then given miso soup and desserts. My favorite of the two desserts was the panna cotta. 

Service was friendly and attentive!

Make reservations to sit at the sushi bar to really get the best experience!

excerpts: Not only was this bizarre for nigiri, I actually burned the top of my mouth slightly!
Wagyu was not as delicious as at Kusakabe
nigiri.author: Xinxin W.
nigiri.review:
TL:DR: 4.5 stars. The restaurant itself is comfortable, cozy, and unpretentious. Very creative nigiris, amazing desserts, and overall great value! 

Reservations at the sushi bar were surprisingly easy. I called on a Wednesday and was able to secure a reservation for 7pm that same Saturday. Never mind that I had omakase on Tuesday and already had plans to eat it again the next day. Omakase all day every day!! Or in my case, every other day. I really hope mercury poisoning is not a real issue... 

Tomo has an air of dignified reserve about him. He's not flashy but you can tell that he knows what he is doing. It almost reminded me of Jiro and his understated dedication to his craft (To be fair, I've never actually been able to secure reservations at Jiro's any of the times I've been to Japan. This statement is made purely off of what I've seen in the documentary and from stalking the front of Jiro's restaurant, catching glimpses of him, and hoping desperately that he would invite us in). Not to say that Tomo's not funny when he wanted to be! The other sushi chef, Atsushi, was equally great, very sweet, and consistently checked in on us to make sure we were enjoying our meal. 

In my opinion, Wako stands out from the other omakase places in the city for a couple of reasons: 

1. Interesting marinades and toppings 
Example 1: Raw abalone with ground up liver sauce 
Example 2: Cold smoked cherry salmon 
Example 3: Blue fin tuna lightly torched and then marinated in jalapano soy 

2. Appetizer/warm dishes are very flavorful and well-balanced. 
Example 1: Uni Chawanmushi. The egg custard was exceptionally flavorful. You can really taste the dashi stock, which in my opinion, gives it a more umami flavor and really underscores the taste of Japanese cuisine. 
Example 2: All the fried stuff (fish, potato ball with wagyu, lotus root, octopus) were lightly battered, fried, and just really well done. 

3. Last, but definitely not least, AMAZING desserts made by one of the waitresses. I think the desserts alone are worth coming here! We had two different types of panna cotta esque desserts (blackberry currant and green tea with white choclate) that left me speechless. 

What prevents this from being a 5 star review is because: 
1. The rice was a bit too soft and sweet 
2. The temperature on some dishes and the temperature change between dishes were very extreme. For example, the anago (Japanese eel), is heated in the oven and comes out blazing hot. Not only was this bizarre for nigiri, I actually burned the top of my mouth slightly!
3. Wagyu was not as delicious as at Kusakabe

excerpts: Nigiri 5 stars.
nigiri.author: Michael H.
nigiri.review:
Nigiri 5 stars. 
Staff 5 stars 

Overall  $130 11 plates for some fish that was not fresh from morning - yes you can tell, as it comes from Spain so flash frozen. Server even told me. 
Plus Uni was in too many dishes (seems they needed to get ride of it) and as A diver who dives for fresh uni regularly this was not on that level. I like this place, but seriously  400+ bucks to eat here. Just because this city is expensive does not mean piggybacking on cost of food has to be.
My opinion it is overpriced. 
But hey if your trying to get laid, this might place might work.

excerpts: The plate of nigiri came out with 8 different choices for you .
nigiri.author: Belinda C.
nigiri.review:
You will be surprise from the outside just how good this food is.  I feel i always walk past this place and i never take notice.  i came here with my friend and we both got the 7 course omakase.    The waitresses here were all so sweet and helpful.  They answered all our questions.   So allow me to describe each dish in order

1)The first dish that came out had 4 small plates. which had a squid dish, sesame tofu, oyster and a warm egg.  All of it was so good and super tasty!  You can tell just how fresh everything was!  

2) The second dish was the sashimi.  It was two slices of tuna and two slices of butterfish (which is my fav!)  Super fresh as well and you don't even need the soy sauce. 

3)Dish number 3 was a dish with pink sticky rice on the bottom and salmon baked with something i forgot on top.   The sauce that went with this made it outstanding.   you will be licking the plate of that sauce.  

4)Dish number four was my #2 favorite of the night (i'll get to #1 soon).  This was a fried shrimp with green tea salt powder.   It was amazing!  I wish i had more of this.  The green tea salt powder was powerful enough to make this dish stand out.  

5) The plate of nigiri came out with 8 different choices for you .   I don't remember what they all were, but i enjoyed all but 2 of it. 

6) For your 6th dish you have an option of the regular miso or the red miso.  My friend and i both got the red miso.   It comes out in black and red bowl so you can't even tell what color it is.  It does taste different. It's not as salty or as tofu-y (if that is even a word).  My friend described the taste as it having an herbal taste with a hint of seafood  taste

7) For dessert we had the passion fruit parfait.  Super light and tasted very tropical 

and finally my number one favorite dish.  We ordered this in addition, to our omakase.  As egg lovers, we just had to get the tamago.   It wasn't just any tamago it was the one without rice, just the egg itself.  When it came to our table it looked like a pound cake.  When you eat it, it sure taste like a super moist pound cake.  This was my #1 favorite dish from this place.  I feel Wako is underrated.  This place is one of the best Japanese place I've been to outside of Asia.  I highly recommend this place if you are a huge sushi lover.

excerpts: For two, we decided to order the $100 omakase nigiri set.
In addition to the set, there were several extra items from the chef sprinkled in with our meal.
At first, I thought the pace of the meal was rather quick, with dishes coming soon after we finished the small plate/box appetizer and first 3 piece nigiri plate.
I was worried I'd be hungry after!
But the pace slowed down significantly after the first two.
nigiri.author: Christina G.
nigiri.review:
Yay! Had a wonderful time at Wako. Made reservations for a Saturday night a week in advance. It is fairly easy to get a reservation using Opentable, but do call if you want a seat at the bar. I tried calling on a Wednesday but the bar seating was already full. Nonetheless, still a great experience. 

The restaurant was small with maybe four or five tables and a bar. It filled up quickly. For two, we decided to order the $100 omakase nigiri set. In addition to the set, there were several extra items from the chef sprinkled in with our meal. At first, I thought the pace of the meal was rather quick, with dishes coming soon after we finished the small plate/box appetizer and first 3 piece nigiri plate. I was worried I'd be hungry after! But the pace slowed down significantly after the first two. We ended up finishing our meal after two hours and felt full and satisfied.

Blue fin tuna belly with caviar and edible gold, uni with salmon roe, anago, and wagyu were some of my favorites. Really delicious and beautiful food presentation! Compared to Kusakabe and Sushi Yoshizumi, I would say Wako had the most comfortable, laid-back atmosphere. Service was also excellent. Definitely deserving of their Michelin-star, and a great place to go for birthdays or a special occasion.

excerpts:
- Wagyu beef nigiri was tender!

The 11 courses option was really filling but if you want more then you can order a coupe pieces of their nigiri.
nigiri.author: Linda L.
nigiri.review:
Recommendation of the day: Go with the 11 course for $130. It was worth every single dollar!

Pros:
- Our waitress was super friendly and clearly articulate every single course to us. She also made a great recommendation to pair her favorite sake with our courses. 
- Presentation of each course was nice. #takeitforthegram
- My favorite was blue fin tuna with caviar and gold on top!
-It was my first time trying uni from Hokkaido and it was creamy and taste pretty fresh. 
- Wagyu beef nigiri was tender!

Cons:
I can't think of any right now.

P.S. The 11 courses option was really filling but if you want more then you can order a coupe pieces of their nigiri. 

Also, you'll need to make a reservation at least 45 days ahead to find a good time during the weekend/holidays.

I have tried Wako, Omasake and Warikuya within one week apart of each other and Wako is definitely my first pick then it'll be Warikuya.

excerpts: I would highly recommend you try their two omakase options: $100 for 12 nigiri pieces, or $82 for a mix of hot and cold dishes, sashimi, and edomae-style nigiri.
nigiri.author: Kate M.
nigiri.review:
I was super impressed by Wako. After having tried multiple high-end sushi restaurants in SF such as Kusakabe, ju-ni, Akiko, and more, I think Wako is almost as good as it gets in the city, barring my gold standard: Kusakabe.

I would highly recommend you try their two omakase options: $100 for 12 nigiri pieces, or $82 for a mix of hot and cold dishes, sashimi, and edomae-style nigiri. 

The space is beautiful, woodsy, and fairly small, so reservations are highly recommended. I sat at the sushi counter for a team dinner and absolutely loved all of the dishes, with my favorites being the otoro, umi masu, and the seasonal flying squid sushi. 

The presentation is artful and beautiful, and Tomo really knows his fish and rice. As he says, the rice is at least 60% more important than fish, and I couldn't agree more!

excerpts: The nigiri has a fresh selection of fish.
The tempura is light, not drenched in oil.
The grilled oysters were tastey.
It was my first time trying a red miso.
It's super flavorful.
nigiri.author: Kris H.
nigiri.review:
Wako is my new fave sushi joint in the city.  I love the hipsterrific woodsy walls and the nice zenny modern lines.  Beautiful ambience.  Friendly service.  It's a small space but not claustrophobic.  

The omakase is pretty fabulous.  The nigiri has a fresh selection of fish.  The tempura is light, not drenched in oil.  The grilled oysters were tastey.  It was my first time trying a red miso.  It's super flavorful.  Highly recommend the omakase.  

The yogurt parfait dessert wasn't memorable, but the house made truffle is pretty darn amazing.  I absolutely wanted more than just one.

excerpts:
There are three omakase menus: a nigiri sushi and sashimi exclusive one, nigiri only, and a seven course mix of these with cooked and raw small plates; we chose the latter.  
Being exhausted from the hectic journey here, I wasn't fully focused on itemizing our courses, given the wide variety of fish in various sashimi and nigiri form. 
The nigiri offerings included salmon, scallop, and yellow tail as one course and saba, king crab, and otoro as another course.  
Wanting to explore a bit more, I added yellowtail dumplings as a supplement.
We were offered the option of red or white miso soup (I had the red).
nigiri.author: Mike C.
nigiri.review:
No joke here.
This is the real deal.  After tailgating Cherylyn N's (http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=eKUGKQRE-Ywi5dY55_zChg) tour of Japanese, specifically omakase,  meals, she named this as a must try destination.  With an upcoming birthday for my pescatarian friend, I made an early weeknight dinner reservation in early December.  A tad late due to the horrendous City traffic from downtown, we were seated at the rear table near the kitchen.  The dining room, comprising of around six tables, was 2/3rd full while the sushi bar was fully occupied.  The menu is pretty simple with an extensive selection of sushi, sashimi, and small plate choices.  There are three omakase menus: a nigiri sushi and sashimi exclusive one, nigiri only, and a seven course mix of these with cooked and raw small plates; we chose the latter.  
Being exhausted from the hectic journey here, I wasn't fully focused on itemizing our courses, given the wide variety of fish in various sashimi and nigiri form. 
Here is a summary of the various offerings in our meal:

The two specials on the menu were the striped jack (sashimi) and the golden eye snapper. 
Yellow tail baked apple and scallop bites were delicious as well as the fish cake tempura, as a different take.  The nigiri offerings included salmon, scallop, and yellow tail as one course and saba, king crab, and otoro as another course.  
Wanting to explore a bit more, I added yellowtail dumplings as a supplement.
We were offered the option of red or white miso soup (I had the red).  
The dessert was not memorable except that it was topped with a chestnut.

The restaurant is not very large and the tables are pretty close together so hope you aren't shy about sharing conversations.  I tried to add the abalone as another supplement, but they had another party waiting for our table so will save it for next time.
The consensus from my other Yelp friends who've reviewed this place is a rousing five stars (4.5 by Cherylynn, but rounded up).
Just don't walk in here expecting a budget dinner or, as Ken K. dubs, "jive ass rolls" (http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=DS0Idr2XDhz5e7ZfSy0dYA) or bento boxes.  Prepared to be transported to Japan.  Sorry, still have yet to go, but, from what I've read....

excerpts: Ala Carte nigiri prices are steep.
Here's a low down of today's nigiri specials and every fish was divine!
nigiri.author: Geoff G.
nigiri.review:
RIDICULOUS! Not the food but the parking! I guess it comes with the territory! Parking on Clement can be insane especially during peak dinner hours. Be prepared to circle the block multiple times as even an illegal space was hard to come by!

Décor is typically Japanese with judicious usage of modern plank-wood on the walls, wooden furnishings and a pretty sushi bar. The vibe was chic and contemporary and more importantly, giving the restaurant a clean look.

As we wanted to try a good cross section of the menu, we opted for a table.

SUSHI:  Wako is high-end. I savored each piece of fish in one mouthful with slow, deliberate bites, as there would be no reruns. Breathe in the pristine freshness, relish how each piece was delicately seasoned and sauced by the chef and notice the textural difference between each fish. Close your eyes if you must lest you might be distracted! Ala Carte nigiri prices are steep. The menu prices are priced per piece, not a pair and you can spend a pretty penny in a hurry! 

Here's a low down of today's nigiri specials and every fish was divine!

1. Hirame (Halibut $6) : a very popular white fish with light and delicate flavor.
2. Shima Aji (Striped Jack $6) : delicious, like a cross between kanpachi (amber jack) and hamachi.
3. Kamasu (Japanese Baracuda $6) : like hirame, it was soft, juicy and light.
4. Kinmedai (Golden Eye Snapper $8) : its texture was not too soft or too crunchy, with a slight sweetness and not fishy.
5. Akamutsu (Rosy Sea Bass $8) : a rare find, not to be missed! A white fish that tasted like toro! (fatty tuna).

The kitchen entrees were equally glorious with some minor hiccups. Even the soy on the table was doctored for better taste. Presentation was the essence.

1. King Crab and Baby Scallop Tempura ($12), light batter and the King Crab were beyond delicious! One piece was given the "isobe" treatment using roasted seaweed (nori) for added flavor. (5/5)
2. Kaisen Chawanmushi ($9 Savory Egg Custard) made with jidori eggs (from specially raised chickens but who cares?). I appreciated the uber smoothness of the custard and the snow crab. But a dollop of uni? Didn't blend so well to my liking with egg custard! (4/5)
3. Blue Fin Tuna cheek on Hotplate (14) was just so so as I preferred my tuna raw. But this was just me! (3/5)
4. Grilled Ink Squid Legs ($8) was nicely salted and crunchy (4/5)
5. Simmered Golden Eye Snapper Head (9) was a delicacy although your cat would love it too! I would have preferred it to be served warmer (temp-wise) and was too sweet  for my liking. (2/5)
6. Grilled Sanma (pike mackerel) with Matsutake mushroom was definitely a work of art! The fish was completely deboned and the mushroom and sweet ginger complemented the umami flavors. Well done! (5/5)

This is the place to come if you are a purist seeking out authenticity and traditionality. I can see careful attention was given to every detail. The server was young, very pleasant although not quite as professional as I would have expected at a high-end place like this. All in all, we had an enjoyable evening!

Gochisosama deshita! (Thank you for the meal!)

excerpts:
What we ordered for two: 
- house made tofu with sea urchin
- fried giant clams
- egg topped with sea urchin
- monkfish liver
- tuna cheek steak
- 5 piece nigiri
- house made green tea mochi
nigiri.author: Janel L.
nigiri.review:
Great service, but for the amount I was paying in terms of food, it's unfortunate that the food did not live up to the hype.

What we ordered for two: 
- house made tofu with sea urchin
- fried giant clams
- egg topped with sea urchin
- monkfish liver
- tuna cheek steak
- 5 piece nigiri
- house made green tea mochi

The tofu with sea urchin was okay in a sense that you can tell that it's house made. Very silky and there was a hint of sesame taste to it.  The giant clams were not very giant. I would not recommend it. The egg topped with sea urchin was mediocre at best. The monkfish liver also had an almost bland taste to it, even though the texture tasted like it was meant to be more creamy. I was a fan of the tuna cheek steak however! It was a very interesting dish. You can really taste both the tuna and steak to every bite. I don't remember which nigiris we got, but I know that each piece was either $9 or $10. For that amount of money for ONE piece, it was not worth it in my opinion.  I also enjoyed the green tea mochi as a dessert.

excerpts: To be honest, the non-nigiri courses were a bit mediocre.
The first course was tasty though, it included some sort of seaweed or kelp and a tiny little seasonal fish that were quite tasty.
The red miso is ok, it's nothing special, but it was nice to try something different.
There was a red snapper with okra, brussel sprouts, and lotus root that was delicious.
All the nigiri pieces were on point, the ones that stood out for me were the Hokkaido Scallop, Maguro, and Spanish Aji.

I'll definitely be back, because I really want to try their Nigiri Omakase,

To Be Continued...
nigiri.author: Aaron C.
nigiri.review:
3.75 STARS, but I know my next visit will be more up my alley.

I've been wanting to try this place for quite some time and am a devout omakase orderer, so I went with the 7 course (per a fellow yelper's tip and my friend wanting to try it).

Fun Fact: The 7 course omakase requires 2 people to order it. 

This place is an interior designer's heaven, super stylish with a very simplistic approach. The placemats and coasters were cool and unique, they gave the heavy wood design a nice touch of style and class.

To be honest, the non-nigiri courses were a bit mediocre. The first course was tasty though, it included some sort of seaweed or kelp and a tiny little seasonal fish that were quite tasty. The red miso is ok, it's nothing special, but it was nice to try something different. There was a red snapper with okra, brussel sprouts, and lotus root that was delicious. All the nigiri pieces were on point, the ones that stood out for me were the Hokkaido Scallop, Maguro, and Spanish Aji.

The customer service was stellar and Tomo, the owner, was very nice and welcoming. They're nearing their 1 year anniversary of being open on Clement. I'll definitely be back, because I really want to try their Nigiri Omakase,

To Be Continued...

excerpts: All the small dishes that came before our nigiri were great.
Loved the deep fried sweet fish stuffed with mushroom.

Some of my favorite nigiri of the night were: 
Toro
Ika
Scallop
Barracuda

Service was good.
nigiri.author: Chris K.
nigiri.review:
What a great sushi place! I took my mom hear to experience her first omakase style dinner. We both got the 7 course omakase and we were stuffed by the end of our meal. 

All the small dishes that came before our nigiri were great. Loved the deep fried sweet fish stuffed with mushroom. I wasn't really impressed with the sashimi dish though. 

Some of my favorite nigiri of the night were: 
Toro
Ika
Scallop
Barracuda

Service was good. The servers were attentive and always came to refill our tea cups. One thing they didn't do though was tell the sushi chef of our dislikes. Our server asked us what we didn't want/like, yet she didn't tell the sushi chef and we got what we didn't want.

excerpts: Each nigiri has its own personality and it melt in your mouth as soon as you bite it.
I'm usually not a fan of octopus, but the one they have doesn't have a slight of fishy smell.
It was the best sushi experience I've ever had and not sure if I'll be able to eat sushi anywhere else.
nigiri.author: Jing W.
nigiri.review: Wako has the best sushi I've ever had in my life so far. They have really taken care of their rice and fish. Each nigiri has its own personality and it melt in your mouth as soon as you bite it. I'm usually not a fan of octopus, but the one they have doesn't have a slight of fishy smell. It was the best sushi experience I've ever had and not sure if I'll be able to eat sushi anywhere else.

excerpts:
- baked yellowtail apple bottom and egg: unique dish and very rich in flavor
- halibut, salmon, stripe jack, and scallop nigiri:
everything on this dish was good, but nothing unique in flavor.
- Tuna belly & bluefin tuna: yum
- crab and salmon roe nigiri:

everything was decent, some had the fishy taste which I wasn't a fan of, but the snappers were my favorite on this nigiri dish
- abalone, yellowtail, gizzard, and uni nigiri: my favorite was the yellowtail and uni on this dish.

Usually I'm not a fan of uni, but it was super fresh that I didn't taste the fishy/oceany taste!
- Otoro from Spain:

Otoro is always super soft and melt-in-your-mouth :D
-
Anago: cooked fish was tasty - mom loved it
- A5 Wagyu:
nigiri.author: Amanda C.
nigiri.review:
Came here for my mother's birthday with reservations on a weekday. The spot is pretty small, but service is great! Authentic, friendly and knowledgable servers which made our experience good. We all had the omakase and I had the Chef Omakase which is slightly more expensive than the regular omakase. However not all the fish tasted fresh, but there were many other dishes that were tasty.

The regular Omakase:
- appetizer with 4 cute mini dishes: one of my favorites of the night
- amberjack & red snapper sashimi: fresh and got me excited for the rest of the meal.
- fried fish ake and veggies with lotus veggies fried: also yum!
- baked yellowtail apple bottom and egg: unique dish and very rich in flavor
- halibut, salmon, stripe jack, and scallop nigiri: everything on this dish was good, but nothing unique in flavor.
- Tuna belly & bluefin tuna: yum
- crab and salmon roe nigiri: decent
- soups were a little too salty - both kinds
- sweet egg cake: very sweet but too full at this point to finish

The chefs Omakase:
- Barracuda, golden eye snapper, red snapper, stripe jack, giant clam: everything was decent, some had the fishy taste which I wasn't a fan of, but the snappers were my favorite on this nigiri dish
- abalone, yellowtail, gizzard, and uni nigiri: my favorite was the yellowtail and uni on this dish. Usually I'm not a fan of uni, but it was super fresh that I didn't taste the fishy/oceany taste!
- Otoro from Spain: Otoro is always super soft and melt-in-your-mouth :D
- Anago: cooked fish was tasty - mom loved it
- A5 Wagyu: Delicious as well!

They provided my mom a panna cotta dessert for her birthday which they did it pretty cute because they came with a few confetti pieces that dropped all over the dessert before placing the dessert in front of my mom. It was indeed tasty and we all ended our meals with a piece of chocolate.

The meal went from super tasty to decent which it should have kept up the tastiness, but the fish probably wasn't too good that day. It was around $355 including tax & tips for 3.

excerpts: The nigiri pieces were tiny and for smaller $92 omakase option, it did not come with premium wagyu, or toro pieces.
Total for four came out to almost $700
and then we went across the street to buy a pizza afterwards.
Service was excellent but tiny portions and was expecting a better experience for the price.
nigiri.author: David D.
nigiri.review: Unfortunately I was pretty disappointed with Wako. I booked very far in advance and was really excited. For the price it was probably one of the worse omakase I have had. It is not a normal full sushi omakase and instead they bring out small and unique plates. It was all good but nothing blew my mind. The nigiri pieces were tiny and for smaller $92 omakase option, it did not come with premium wagyu, or toro pieces. Total for four came out to almost $700 and then we went across the street to buy a pizza afterwards. Service was excellent but tiny portions and was expecting a better experience for the price.

excerpts: Great service and well balanced with Nigiri, Appetizers, and Hot Dishes
nigiri.author: Peter W.
nigiri.review: Great service and well balanced with Nigiri, Appetizers, and Hot Dishes

excerpts: It included 3 small plates, 4 pcs sashimi, 1  bincho-grill, 3 tempura, 7 pcs nigiri, miso soup and dessert.
I won't go into detail about everything that we ate, but I will confirm that everything was exceptional!
