They're definitely not trying to fill you up on carbs, leaving you plenty of room to really enjoy the fish. Wako has also brought upon my appreciation for uni. I've never really had good uni before this meal, and the uni nigiri with the shiso leaf tucked in between the rice was perfect. The brine-y flavor wasn't overwhelming, but I still got a great flavor of the ocean. Another highlight was the crab nigiri, which was so tender. It was a simple bite, but the perfect way to highlight the crab. 

The meal is finished off with a housemade strawberry mousse, maintaining that light quality that connected the entire omakase. The fresh strawberry chunks made it refreshing, and the mousse itself wasn't at all heavy or creamy. They also serve a complimentary piece of chocolate that they also make themselves, finishing off with a bit of decadence that you didn't realize you wanted after an amazing meal. 

Wako Sushi is without a doubt one of my favorite Japanese spots in San Francisco, and I highly recommend it to anyone, sushi lover or not!

excerpts:
and there isn't anything phenomenally outstanding

#3: 7 Nigiri
- Beautifully made and very tasty!
nigiri.author: Sarah K.
nigiri.review:
Hello Wako! To me you are Maruya in the mission minus the big bill! 

I went here couple days ago and I had a late lunch around 3pm and went in around 6 so my friend and I decided to opt for the smaller course Omakaze. Before our official course meal started, we ordered a SEASONAL mushroom soup -- this mushroom grows in Japan (also seattle and canada apparently) only under pine trees and because they grow and are at optimal in taste during this time, Wako only offers this soup in Oct/Nov months. 

Their smaller Omakaze menu doesn't change, but they will change up their menu close to quarterly basis for their bigger Omakaze.

Courses:

#1: Tofu and salad
- Tofu was super soft (possibly home-made) but a bit bland and wasn't too special for me.

#2: Miso glazed sea bass
- Pretty good but it's not unique to Wako and there isn't anything phenomenally outstanding

#3: 7 Nigiri
- Beautifully made and very tasty! I have to say.. the rice is better at Maruya but the cut of the fish and how it is prepared is exceptional! I LOVED IT. My favorite was (and if you don't do omakaze try this at least) red snapper with cherry blossom leaf, salt and lemon. It melted in my mouth and I think I had a tear in my eye. ;) 

#4: Finished with red miso soup which was great and unique.

#5: mini home-made chocolate

I highly recommend it and it will not break your bank.

excerpts: One thing that's kinda unique about this place: a bunch of pieces of nigiri that we had were lightly seared via blow-torch.
It was a treat watching the chef blow-torch the fish.
Also, can I just say, amazing knife work on all the fish.
Overall, a 5/5 place for sushi, but make sure you reserve ahead of time.
This place also has one of the best price for the quality/quantity of sushi you get.
We will be coming back again very soon.
nigiri.author: Sharon L.
nigiri.review: Another stellar SF sushi bar! We came here on Saturday evening and sat at the sushi bar. If you want the Omakase set, please be aware that you'll have to get a bar seating (which you can only get by calling them, OpenTable reservations are for table only). One thing that's kinda unique about this place: a bunch of pieces of nigiri that we had were lightly seared via blow-torch. It was a treat watching the chef blow-torch the fish. Also, can I just say, amazing knife work on all the fish. Overall, a 5/5 place for sushi, but make sure you reserve ahead of time. This place also has one of the best price for the quality/quantity of sushi you get. We will be coming back again very soon.

excerpts: The best part of the meal was the nigiri, however they were pricey at $5-9/piece.
nigiri.author: Inga W.
nigiri.review:
I was very surprised to see all the 5 star reviews, hardly ever happens and definitely never in new restaurants as they are working out their kinks.   But it's a few blocks from my house so I wanted to support my hood.

My hubby and I went for a Friday date night. We were excited to try something new and creative and we're all about food adventure. 

Unfortunately the food just wasn't great, the dishes were a bit bland and the portions pretty small and since fish is light, we ordered many but still walked away hungry.

The miso black cod had tons of bones in it, which just shouldn't be served in a fillet and the portions small.

We had the monkfish liver pate, it was interesting but a bit dry and lacking in flavor. 

The hand rolls didn't have much fish.  The best part of the meal was the nigiri, however they were pricey at $5-9/piece.  

The service was very slow, didn't refill our drinks and the rolls took forever, we waited over 30 minutes, while the hot dishes came out fairly fast.  The waitress apologized for the bad service and said hoped we'd come back again.  In this situation they should have comped some of the food and given us something on the house while we waited. 

After dinner we went over to another place for dessert and drinks, and if it wasn't so late I would have shared an entree as well.  

The bill came to $130 with tip, given the great meals you can have in SF for that price, including great sushi, it just wasn't worth it and I'm not looking to come back again.

excerpts: Size - Some might find their nigiri to be on the smaller side.
And, every nigiri is prepared right before served.
I really hate to compare Wako to Maruya since Mr. J and I like them both.
nigiri.author: Kay Y.
nigiri.review:
I never write reviews...  But, I certainly think Wako deserves my very first review!

While the whole town is hyping over the opening of Kusakabe, Mr. J and I decided to try this even newer, shy of a month old joint first.  I got home around 8:30 pm on Friday night after a long streak of working weeks and was telling Mr. J that we haven't had time to really enjoy a meal together.  So, maybe we should go somewhere nice for dinner.  Mr. J was laughing at me and said no good place would have an open reservation on a Friday night.  Well, I decided it doesn't hurt to try and gave Wako a call to see if their sushi bar is available at 9 pm.  I won't lie, but I was surprised when the lady over the phone told me that they are available.  And there, Mr. J and I rushed out the door.  On the drive over there, we kept thinking if we made the right decision and will we be disappointed at the end of the night.

When we walked into Wako, I immediately fell in love with its cozy and inviting environment.  After identifying ourselves, the server sat us down at the best seats in the house with the reserved sign.  There are 10 seats at the bar and we got the perfect front view of Tomo-san and Atsushi-san!  Wako offers four or seven course omakase option and Mr. J and I went for the seven course one and added a few a la carte items as well.  I won't go into too much detail of our dishes as I believe a picture is worth a thousand words.  But, there are a few things worth mentioning.

*** Rice - Mr. J and I are very particular and picky when it comes to the sushi rice.  We both agreed that the sushi rice at Wako is probably the best we've had in the bay area.

*** Size - Some might find their nigiri to be on the smaller side.  But, I find them to be the perfect size to be eaten with hands in one bite.

*** Rhythm - Tomo-san always asks if he may start preparing the next sushi.  And, every nigiri is prepared right before served.  I really hate to compare Wako to Maruya since Mr. J and I like them both.  But, we've seen fishes been sliced together beforehand at Maruya the last time we were there at the sushi bar.

*** Tamago - Not your typical tamago at the sushi restaurant here.  The type they served is Kasutera, the kind that look and taste like the Japanese Castella cake.  And, it's Mr. J's favorite!  Tomo-san asked if we had this kind of tamago before and wanted our opinion.  After I took a bite and he saw my big smile, he said no words are needed as he can see it in my smile.

*** Dessert - I cannot express enough the importance of a dessert at the end of every meal.  I don't care how good of a meal I had if their dessert is weak.  A great dessert = a perfecting ending to a meal.  Mmmm, I am still drooling over their house made matcha daifuku!

Tomo-san and Atsushi-san are both funny and interactive.  They totally made our night a happy one!  Mr. J and I were the last two to leave with two very full and happy tummies!  We'll be back soon!!

excerpts: We got two drinks, the omakases, and a couple of nigiri, which totaled $270.
It's a little pricey but worth the quality!
The menu changes every couple of months
so there's good reason to always come back
nigiri.author: Bianca W.
nigiri.review:
I brought my bestie here for her birthday and we both really enjoyed the experience! I've been dying to come here because I love omakase and I like that theirs has different preparation styles (apps, grilled, sashimi, etc). 

We got two drinks, the omakases, and a couple of nigiri, which totaled $270. It's a little pricey but worth the quality! The menu changes every couple of months so there's good reason to always come back :)

excerpts: Omakase was beautifully done and offered great line up of various sashimi and nigiri pieces, along with tempura and other seasonal little dishes that both delight the eyes and the tastebuds.
Goma tofu was delightful and loved the custard egg.
Love to revisit again.
nigiri.author: Stephanie L.
nigiri.review: A really lovely meal at the sushi counter. Omakase was beautifully done and offered great line up of various sashimi and nigiri pieces, along with tempura and other seasonal little dishes that both delight the eyes and the tastebuds. Goma tofu was delightful and loved the custard egg. Love to revisit again.

excerpts: a5 wagyu miso stew , fresh assorted crab and seaweed , and some nigiri !
nigiri.author: Li S.
nigiri.review: So I thought I'll try a new #sushi spot in #sf and it was ok. The food overall wasn't too bad, but you can definitely get much better with the sane atmosphere. Order: raw squid, a5 wagyu miso stew , fresh assorted crab and seaweed , and some nigiri !

excerpts: bincho-grill (1), tempura (3), nigiri (7pcs.), miso soup, dessert.
Right down to the nigiri, because this is what I like about the place.
Best fish of the day is what's this is all about.
No soy sauce beyond this point.
Everything was lightly prepped without heavy taste.
This is where you find out if the fish is fresh or not.
My favorite of the nigiri was the Snow Crab.
Very close to what I had in Hokkaido Japan.
Then there was scallop which was lightly seared.
Very juicy and almost melted in my mouth (like tofu, but it has a nice caramel scallop taste).
Then it was the toro... and finishing the authentic Hokkaido Uni.
You can actually see that the box had hokkaido sticker on it.
You might get more bang for the buck if your a nigiri person.
nigiri.author: Eric Y.
nigiri.review:
Tuesday - Called at 5:20pm to make a reservation for Sunday at 6:30pm. Very accommodating over the phone. Please do make sure that you call during their reservation acceptance hrs. On Saturday, I had to call in to make a last minute change to add 2 more people to the party. Again, they made it happen and we sat at the sushi bar. 

Our pleasure and first time was given to Tomo-san who serves around the corner are of the sushi bar. Tomo-san started joking with us when he found out that one person was late. He said, "Is the person here? Looking for parking?" I said, "yes". He said, "oh no... Good luck!" hahaha! The friend ended up spending 15 mins looking for parking. They didn't rush us to order since our timeframe was blocked off specifically for us to enjoy the dinner. 

Our party for 4 did the 7 course omakase for $68/head. 
Seven Course 68 small plates (3), sashimi (4pcs.) bincho-grill (1), tempura (3), nigiri (7pcs.), miso soup, dessert.

The four piece sashimi included King Salmon and Hamachi. Honestly, nothing special for this plate.. King salmon wasn't buttery or creamy enough. Just wasn't a big wow factor for this. 

I'm going to skip the grill stuff and the tempura stuff. 

Right down to the nigiri, because this is what I like about the place. Best fish of the day is what's this is all about. No soy sauce beyond this point. Everything was lightly prepped without heavy taste. This is where you find out if the fish is fresh or not. My favorite of the nigiri was the Snow Crab. Very close to what I had in Hokkaido Japan. Then there was scallop which was lightly seared. Very juicy and almost melted in my mouth (like tofu, but it has a nice caramel scallop taste). Then it was the toro... and finishing the authentic Hokkaido Uni. You can actually see that the box had hokkaido sticker on it. Very sweet! 

We also had a drink with Tomo-san.. Be sure to order up the Banana Beer that they have. Nothing better than drinking up with the sushi chef and talking about food. Tomo said he loved izakaya's in San Mateo area.   

~Note~

We requested one of the omakase to have more seared and more cooked items since our friend wasn't a big raw fish eater. Tomo-san was nice and served up some specials for her. He made sure that each item was okay and that she liked what was served. 

Wish the server were more prompted on refilling tea. We had to ask for a pot since we kept asking for refills. 

If I were to do it again, I would do 4 course meal, use the $25 difference and order some different stuff on the menu. You might get more bang for the buck if your a nigiri person. 

Oh, don't miss out on the housemade dessert and the chocolate.

excerpts: For my appetite the 7-course omakase was not enough and I needed to interrupt with 8 more pieces of nigiri before finishing off with dessert.
I enjoyed the small plates, bincho-grill, and tempura, which were perfectly cooked or fried.
The nigri was beautifully present and tasty to boot but the cuts were smaller than I expected.
At least the chefs downsized the rice to create the right ratio.
Wako is a great for a sushi date night, and reminiscent of Koo, but be prepared for the bill.
nigiri.author: Andrew W.
nigiri.review:
I have been on a sushi cleanse for the past six months. For six tortuous months, I have watched my friends, strangers, television hosts eat, discuss, and enjoy sushi. Now, I cannot even remember why I gave up sushi, but I am so glad that Wako was my introduction back into the wonderful world of sushi.

For my return, I decided that reservations for the sushi bar and the seven course omakase were the way to go. Reservations were easy to get for an early weekday dinner but parking was a headache. If you cannot find parking on Clement, save your gas and drive one block down to Geary.

The chefs and waitresses at Wako are very attentive and friendly when the restaurant is slower, so I am glad that my experienced ended before the dinner rush. For my appetite the 7-course omakase was not enough and I needed to interrupt with 8 more pieces of nigiri before finishing off with dessert. I enjoyed the small plates, bincho-grill, and tempura, which were perfectly cooked or fried. The nigri was beautifully present and tasty to boot but the cuts were smaller than I expected. At least the chefs downsized the rice to create the right ratio. Wako is a great for a sushi date night, and reminiscent of Koo, but be prepared for the bill. Eating here is an expensive experience. 

What I recommend:
- omakase (changes every month according to the chefs)
- anago
- tamago (bready and sweet)

excerpts: tip: don't dip the pre-sauced nigiri in the wasabi soy mixture.
Skin on when requested but otherwise very unique selection of nigiri.
The stewed pear with mackerel was overcooked.
Giant clam nigiri had out of this world texture so that has to be the highlight of the night more so than the toro and uni cuz that's really standard omakase stuff.
nigiri.author: Jacky K C.
nigiri.review:
tip: don't dip the pre-sauced nigiri in the wasabi soy mixture.

Some imperfections, tempura not crispy. Skin on when requested but otherwise very unique selection of nigiri.  The stewed pear with mackerel was overcooked. Uni complements the egg really well.  

Giant clam nigiri had out of this world texture so that has to be the highlight of the night more so than the toro and uni cuz that's really standard omakase stuff.

excerpts: the rice is so good and rightly proportioned for each piece of nigiri.
I had the buttered snow carb and chutoro nigiri and a mentaiko temaki.
Chu toro alone is underrated and should be looked into more.
It's better IMO than otoro bc it is less greasy and maintains the tunas true flavor.
nigiri.author: Megan L.
nigiri.review:
modern japanese, fresh sushi, and comfort.  Modern wooden interior with a bright and cozy feel. None of the boring dim lit jazz feeling that too many sushi places go for.

Uni chawanmushi is amazing, rich dashi broth with fish, shiitake, mochi and uni on top. This is a mid $$$$ range sushi place but it's magic bc the rice is so good and rightly proportioned for each piece of nigiri. I had the buttered snow carb and chutoro nigiri and a mentaiko temaki. Chu toro alone is underrated and should be looked into more. It's better IMO than otoro bc it is less greasy and maintains the tunas true flavor. Sitting at the bar allows you to see the care and preparation that goes into each piece of sushi. 

Everything on the menu besides sushi is also great and warming, making the whole selection and experience awesome. 

Parking is miserable, but I would struggle again to eat at wako.

excerpts: 12/20 2nd time coming here this time to do the omakase nigiri special.
so we were able to try more nigiri rather than usual course meal.
Id prefer this one over the course if u wanna try fresh nigiri fresh uni fresh slices from all over the world this is the one.
The plates kept getting better and better ending in wagyu again omg that is the best thing here one must try uni for the daring and blue fin tuna belly
oh my.
definitely not ur california roll type of sushi place 10/10 still great quick service with very informative staff
nigiri.author: Charles D.
nigiri.review: 12/20 2nd time coming here this time to do the omakase nigiri special. so we were able to try more nigiri rather than usual course meal. Id prefer this one over the course if u wanna try fresh nigiri fresh uni fresh slices from all over the world this is the one. The plates kept getting better and better ending in wagyu again omg that is the best thing here one must try uni for the daring and blue fin tuna belly oh my. definitely not ur california roll type of sushi place 10/10 still great quick service with very informative staff

excerpts: This place is focus on omakase & Al la Carte nigiri with upgrades by Japanese sushi chef Their size & price was better than kusakabe..
($$$$) and the nigiri were professional Japanese sushi from sushi rice to each fish nigiri..of how it's made..
nigiri.author: Le Chef
nigiri.review:
This place is focus on omakase & Al la Carte nigiri with upgrades by Japanese sushi chef Their size & price was better than kusakabe..($$$$) and the nigiri were professional Japanese sushi from sushi rice to each fish nigiri..of how it's made.. Too bad they don't use red vinegar with More umami flavor for their sushi rice..  

I didn't enjoy the tai, cuz it's lacking flavor and taste. It's too boring..as i felt sushi chef were lacking passion..

Felt the chef don't have natural passion but trying a lot but they really have the potential become excellent.  

bluefin tuna w/jalapeño torched: A+
Uni:A  Fresh 
Tai: B- tasteless 
Barracuda: B+ very hard white fish 
Wagyu beef: A+ sweet ponzu w/momiji aroshi scallion garlic chip.. Delicious! 
Anago: A nice Anago sauce! 

Gindara w/nasu & okra dashi broth: A++ 
(Super delicious!)

Salmon Kama shioyaki: B not enough salt.. Tasteless.. But it was soft & fresh

excerpts: Each nigiri they hand out is perfectly crafted and just mmm mmm melts in your mouth.
Every single piece tasted so different from the other but still managed to cause an extravaganza in your mouth.
I've never had a sushi experience like this before!
The omakase also comes along with a soup and two small plates which also delight the taste buds in your mouth.
nigiri.author: Kim N.
nigiri.review:
Definitely one of the best sushi places in the bay area. 

$45 for the best omakase I've ever had?! Yes please! My boyfriend and I definitely put our trust into these sushi chefs, and we did not regret it! Each nigiri they hand out is perfectly crafted and just mmm mmm melts in your mouth. Every single piece tasted so different from the other but still managed to cause an extravaganza in your mouth.  I've never had a sushi experience like this before! The omakase also comes along with a soup and two small plates which also delight the taste buds in your mouth. The tea is also delightful along with your meal! 

And oh man! The silverware! From the teapot, to the plates, to the utensils, the silverware is so appealing to the eyes. The whole restaurant is nicely decorated, but the silverware just seals the deal. 

Also, the sushi chefs were absolutely charming! My boyfriend and I were 19 when we decided to come here. So we couldn't order any beer or sake. But! They still offered to cheers KAMPAI! with our tea cups and their alcoholic beverages. Made us feel very relaxed and engaged during our meal. They also answer all your questions enthusiastically and kindly if you have any while you sit at the sushi bar. Also, they're open to getting to know their customers which is always a plus!!! Waitress was nice too. They were all booked for the day, but she managed to slip us in for two seats at the sushi bar an hour later. 

Overall, this is the best sushi experience I've had thus far! I'm so glad my boyfriend and I decided to splurge on sushi during our visit to SF that day! Definitely would give it a ten stars if I could!

excerpts: We sat at the chef's counter and had the nigiri omakase.
Each piece of nigiri was a whirl of flavours and textures.
It was so perfect.
The most pleasant Japanese meal I've had in San Francisco so far.
(The chef is really nice too and the venue pretty cool with good music.)
nigiri.author: Olivia M.
nigiri.review: We sat at the chef's counter and had the nigiri omakase. Each piece of nigiri was a whirl of flavours and textures. It was so perfect. The most pleasant Japanese meal I've had in San Francisco so far. (The chef is really nice too and the venue pretty cool with good music.)

excerpts: We did the $100 omakase nigiri menu.
The fish was not as prepped as much as at Kusakabe or Omakase
but there were was some interesting flavors added to the fish.
We started with a small 4 appetizers plate that was good.
There was also miso soup in addition to the 12 pieces of nigiri.
We also added an extra 3 pieces of nigiri.
All the fish was very fresh though not spectacular.
I guess the day of 2 pieces of nigiri of the same fish for a reasonable price is gone!
LOL
We notice all the upper tier of sushi restaurants only offer 1 piece for almost what we used to pay for 2 pieces not that long ago.
Is the quality that much better?
Not sure it is.
nigiri.author: Kell M.
nigiri.review:
We enjoyed our dinner here.  It is a really beautiful little restaurant.  All their various dishes they use to plate the food were beautiful.  We did the $100 omakase nigiri menu.  The fish was not as prepped as much as at Kusakabe or Omakase but there were was some interesting flavors added to the fish.  We started with a small 4 appetizers plate that was good.  There was also miso soup in addition to the 12 pieces of nigiri.  And we ended with a small dessert that was tasty.

We also added an extra 3 pieces of nigiri.  All the fish was very fresh though not spectacular.  The service was perfect!

I guess the day of 2 pieces of nigiri of the same fish for a reasonable price is gone!  LOL  We notice all the upper tier of sushi restaurants only offer 1 piece for almost what we used to pay for 2 pieces not that long ago.  Is the quality that much better?  Not sure it is.

excerpts: We had the nigiri Omakase and had the freshest selections.
I can't rave enough about this place
and I just hope it stays consistent.
Make sure to call early to reserve a table as it stays booked even on a rainy Sunday!
I'm definitely a regular and will keep coming back.
I recommend starting with the first Omakase option on the menu and the nigiri Omakase for your 2nd time!
nigiri.author: Pam V.
nigiri.review: Back for another mindblowing experience and it was indeed a no fail! We had the nigiri Omakase and had the freshest selections. I can't rave enough about this place and I just hope it stays consistent. Make sure to call early to reserve a table as it stays booked even on a rainy Sunday! I'm definitely a regular and will keep coming back. I recommend starting with the first Omakase option on the menu and the nigiri Omakase for your 2nd time!

excerpts: That would mean sitting through dozens of rather mundane pieces of nigiri.
nigiri.author: Jason C.
nigiri.review:
Out of Wako, Kusakabe and Maruya, Wako is probably my favorite.  But that isn't saying much.  The sushi here, for someone who lived in Tokyo for 4 years, then lived in NYC for 8 years (and bemoaned how there were only two Tokyo-grade sushi joints in all of NYC), was inoffensive.  

Rice was properly flavored, though extremely delicately so.  What does it mean when flavor is so subtle it's almost indiscernible?

Fish was fine, though ultimately uninspiring.  Bland.  When fish is good, it tastes like life.  This was just okay.

Really, inoffensive is the word that comes to mind.  Where is the rich, nuanced flavor of good rice, balanced with sweetness and sourness and a rich oily piece of live aji on top?  

Actually, the kohada was pretty decent.  Thinking about the good pieces, you might be able to make a passable meal if you could just select the few items that are actually pretty good.  But I'm not sure it's worth the effort to figure out what all those pieces are.  That would mean sitting through dozens of rather mundane pieces of nigiri.

excerpts: The barracuda nigiri was very memorable, as were the hand rolls.
But the Wagyu nigiri was nothin short of remarkable.
nigiri.author: Isaac P.
nigiri.review:
Along with Yasuda in Tokyo and Arami in Chicago, the best sushi I've ever enjoyed. 

Went there for Christmas Eve with my wife. We were in an indulgent mood, and perhaps over-ordered by a dish or three. Each was better than the last. The barracuda nigiri was very memorable, as were the hand rolls. But the Wagyu nigiri was nothin short of remarkable. The most tender and delectable piece of meat I've tasted.

Will definitely return.

excerpts: My boyfriend really enjoys nigiri and completely devoured anything that was placed on his plate.
This is a fresh fish place so if you're looking for rolls or chicken teriyaki - this may not be the place to go.
Great service and atmosphere - will definitely be coming again.
nigiri.author: Tiffany L.
nigiri.review: So great to see a traditional Japanese restaurant in the neighborhood. It's beautifully decorated with a sleek design - though it's quite small so I would call ahead if you have a large party. My boyfriend really enjoys nigiri and completely devoured anything that was placed on his plate. This is a fresh fish place so if you're looking for rolls or chicken teriyaki - this may not be the place to go. Great service and atmosphere - will definitely be coming again.

excerpts: The nigiri was out of this world.
The chef explained the origin of each piece and they all melted in your mouth.
It was an intimate experience sitting at the chef's table and watching your meal unfold with such precision and passion.
This is definitely a pricey choice, but a great way to celebrate a special occasion.
nigiri.author: Tran T.
nigiri.review: Details, details, details!! Wako came highly recommended to us by a friend who lives in SF. Hubby and I ordered the omakase and it was an amazing experience from start to finish. I can't recall all the dishes, but the presentation was unique and beautiful. The nigiri was out of this world. The chef explained the origin of each piece and they all melted in your mouth. It was an intimate experience sitting at the chef's table and watching your meal unfold with such precision and passion. This is definitely a pricey choice, but a great way to celebrate a special occasion.

excerpts: We sat at the bar and had the omakase nigiri.
nigiri.author: P K.
nigiri.review:
This has to be the best sushi in town. 
We sat at the bar and had the omakase nigiri. 

Highlights were the sea eel, fatty tuna, wagyu, house marinated ikura and Hokkaido uni. Basically it was all delicious. I would rate this better quality, value and less pretentious than Kusakabe which was my top pick before coming here. 

We had about 16pcs and came to about $125 per person. Super personable chef too!

excerpts: Watching Tomo, a three-time U.S. Sushi MasterChef Champion, make your nigiri is a pleasure in itself.
The ambiance is modern, clean (but not sterile), and comfortable.
Best nigiri: yellowtail, scallop, mackerel, tuna, scallop (ask to keep scallop raw/un-grilled).
Mediocre nigiri: chinook king salmon (too soft and mushy)
Drinks:
nigiri.author: Catherine C.
nigiri.review:
This is very close to a 5-star for me, but not quite there. 

Tomo, the sushi chef and owner, has endless patience answering our pestering questions about sushi, food, and life in general. Yes, if you go to Wako, sit at the sushi bar. Watching Tomo, a three-time U.S. Sushi MasterChef Champion, make your nigiri is a pleasure in itself. The ambiance is modern, clean (but not sterile), and comfortable. Great place to go on a fancy date.  

Now onto the food itself:  
Chirashi - Fresh but small slices. Has a dabble of uni included. I was disappointed that Tomo decided to use smoked salmon instead of fresh salmon though. For $36, I expected better.  

Best nigiri: yellowtail, scallop, mackerel, tuna, scallop (ask to keep scallop raw/un-grilled).  

Mediocre nigiri: chinook king salmon (too soft and mushy)  Drinks: Abbey Road sake (smooth, fruity, no aftertaste). 

The barley tea here is delightful too.  Desserts: House made black sesame daifuku (mochi) by one of the waitresses = amazeballs she also makes a killer panna cotta and green tea mochi.

excerpts: Wow -- Nigiri Omakase, amazing, interesting, all good (though I'm not particularly fond of monkfish liver) -- Special Uni and Unagi at the end, good small plates, kept the shrimp tempura flowing for my 8 year old (who ate 1/2 my nigiri anyway).
Really fresh fish, mostly brought in from Japan, but some local. amberjack, multiple kinds of tuna, Abalone, amazing small scallops.
nigiri.author: Andrew C.
nigiri.review:
Wow -- Nigiri Omakase, amazing, interesting, all good (though I'm not particularly fond of monkfish liver) -- Special Uni and Unagi at the end, good small plates, kept the shrimp tempura flowing for my 8 year old (who ate 1/2 my nigiri anyway). Really fresh fish, mostly brought in from Japan, but some local. amberjack, multiple kinds of tuna, Abalone, amazing small scallops. The Hamachi was smoked, which i usually don't care for, but still good. 

This is not your usual sushi place. No soyu to add tons of wasabi to and hide the lack of fresh fish ... very traditional Japanese, like what you'd get in a traditional hotel in Japan, including some items that we were not quite sure what they were ... 

Great service. After we left, they called to tell us we left them an extra $100 (two $100 bills stuck together) -- Could not believe it! Went back and got it, but left an extra tip ... Highly, highly recommended!!

excerpts: Second, although a small piece nigiri for $8-$13 may seem expensive, the actually quality of the cuts are quite excellent and definitely fresh.
You will get to enjoy some of the freshest flavors across the globe.
nigiri.author: Nick Y.
nigiri.review:
We came here because Wako provided the traditional Japanese Sushi experience we missed so much since we moved away from Japan. Wako is not the kind of restaurant that have fancy plating or over the top decoration/landscaping. No, these are not what traditional sushi is about. Instead, Wako excelled in two paradigms of excellent sushi making/service. First, they had absolutely excellent customer service: warm, welcoming, and very much down-to-earth-friendly. Second, although a small piece nigiri for $8-$13 may seem expensive, the actually quality of the cuts are quite excellent and definitely fresh. You will get to enjoy some of the freshest flavors across the globe. I will definitely be back for another round of "Omakase" when I'm back in San Francisco.

Cheers to Tomo and Goji ( I apologize if I have misspelled your names).

excerpts: Incredibly fresh and authentic nigiri (you must do the Omakase here) --
delicious uni, barracuda, ankimo, halibut, and toro.
nigiri.author: Roy C.
nigiri.review:
I'm going keep this one short, since there's not much more to say other than: Wako is the best sushi in SF. 

Incredibly fresh and authentic nigiri (you must do the Omakase here) -- delicious uni, barracuda, ankimo, halibut, and toro. The hot dishes were also all delicious. 

Love this place.

excerpts: As an extra we ordered Satsuma Wagyu nigiri sushi for ten dollars each.
nigiri.author: Mark M.
nigiri.review:
A gem.  A diamond.   
Ordered the Omakase dinner for $76...
It was a seven course dinner.
Tsukidashi (with hint of new year delicacies including kazunoko), assorted sashimi with house made soy sauce, tempura, yaki-mono (baked oyster and scallops), assorted sushi, akadashi miso soup and finished with white wine mouse.
Presentation of food was exquisite.
Impressed with the ceramic ware used to serve each dish.

As an extra we ordered Satsuma Wagyu nigiri sushi for ten dollars each.
A melt in your mouth experience.

We enjoyed the nice selection of sake..

This restaurant just opened in July of 2014.  Wako is definitely a five star restaurant and to those who put three stars on review because portions are small and complain that his stomach did not get full doesn't really know how to appreciate thoughtfully presented and prepared essence of Japanese kaiseki cuisine.

I wish I lived nearby so that I can be a najimi kyaku.

excerpts: We order the 7 course omakase and a few other pieces of nigiri to top off the tank.
The sushi was clean and fresh.
nigiri.author: Kelson H.
nigiri.review:
Made reservations ahead of time. The sushi here was fantastic and the place was very clean. 

We order the 7 course omakase and a few other pieces of nigiri to top off the tank.  The sushi was clean and fresh.  Enjoy each bite!  

Decor: 5
Food:5
Service: 5  

Would I go back? You bet your pastrami I would!

excerpts: The topping is only a small part of the equation and a prerequisite to making good nigiri.
Tomo-san's rice, creative preparation, laser focused attention to detail and hospitality set him very far apart from the rest of the pack.
nigiri.author: Will H.
nigiri.review:
I'm a lifelong lover of sushi and have been to most of the highest rated sushi bars in Tokyo.  After 10+ meals here, I would rather eat at Wako than most of them. It is without a doubt the best sushi bar in Northern California.

Most sushi bars can get a fresh selection of fish from Tsukiji now days.  The topping is only a small part of the equation and a prerequisite to making good nigiri.  Tomo-san's rice, creative preparation, laser focused attention to detail and hospitality set him very far apart from the rest of the pack.  Not to mention that the decor and design of Wako look like a three star Michelin sushi bar that was transported straight from Ginza.

Simply incredible.  Go.

excerpts:
- nigiri: salmon, saba, and anago
- giant fried clam (wouldn't call it giant but was good)
nigiri.author: Gina R.
nigiri.review:
Ordered a la care tonight and everything was delic! Pricey but delic.

- nigiri: salmon, saba, and anago
- giant fried clam (wouldn't call it giant but was good)
- salmon skin handroll
- sesame mochi for dessert yum!
- complimentary house made chocolate was so good

Next time will have to try omakase.

excerpts: I had the omakase nigiri at the sushi bar and it was an evening to remember.
One cannot explain the variety of tastes.
You simply have to try.
Highly recommend.
It also has a Michelin star which is always cool:)
nigiri.author: Paul G.
nigiri.review: You should dine at Wako if you want a truly unique experience. However, if you are starving the portions are quite small and expensive. With that being said, you don't come here to get filled up, you come here to taste the freshest selections the chef has to offer. I had the omakase nigiri at the sushi bar and it was an evening to remember. One cannot explain the variety of tastes. You simply have to try. Highly recommend. It also has a Michelin star which is always cool:)

excerpts: You can get 7 course omakase with cooked food for $75 or all nigiri for MP.
I got the 7 course
and it was so yummy.
A little bit of everything.
The highlight was the 8 different nigiri you get.
No soy sauce needed.
Super fresh.
Loved it all.
nigiri.author: Karen H.
nigiri.review:
Very small place, but decor is nice and staff is friendly. I wanted to sit at the bar, but they only do 6pm, 630, and 8pm. I wanted 7pm so we had to sit at a table. You can get 7 course omakase with cooked food for $75 or all nigiri for MP. I got the 7 course and it was so yummy. A little bit of everything. The highlight was the 8 different nigiri you get. No soy sauce needed. Super fresh. Loved it all. The rice was super good. 

We also added a la carte items: ankimo, tomago, tuna roll, steam egg. All were very yummy and the price was decent. 

I haven't had good quality Japanese food in awhile and I am sure there are a lot better places out there, but I was very satisfied!

excerpts: The 7 pieces of nigiri followed were the highlights of the meal.
The fish super fresh.
The rice chewy and perfectedly cooked.
Each nigiri was nicely seasoned, with a hint of citrus or a pinch of wasabi.
The fish's distinctive flavors were not masked, but elevated.
What ended a wonderful meal was the matcha daifuku, pumped with a creamy filling similar to Beard Papa's famous cream puffs.
nigiri.author: Candice B.
nigiri.review:
Wako has a very reasonably priced omakase menu. The first course consists of a beautifully crafted seasonal vegetable dish, very light, very appetizing.  Almost like an amuse bouche.  Then the grill dish we had was a nicely chared pieced of salmon, with the right amount of fat.  It was almost as buttery and decadent as a piece of black cod.  The 7 pieces of nigiri followed were the highlights of the meal.  The fish super fresh.  The rice chewy and perfectedly cooked.  Each nigiri was nicely seasoned, with a hint of citrus or a pinch of wasabi.  The fish's distinctive flavors were not masked, but elevated.  What ended a wonderful meal was the matcha daifuku, pumped with a creamy filling similar to Beard Papa's famous cream puffs.  Not overly sweet, just the perfect little sweet note to end your meal. 

All for under $50 (excludes tax and tips.)  I think that's a steal.

excerpts: The seven course omakase was a good value with the sushi and eight pieces of the best nigiri I've ever had.
Really enjoyed the scallop and salmon.
nigiri.author: Pearl L.
nigiri.review: The seven course omakase was a good value with the sushi and eight pieces of the best nigiri I've ever had. Really enjoyed the scallop and salmon.

excerpts: The food is broken down into grilled pates, appetizers, small plates, rolls, and nigiri.
This isn't a cheap restaurant.
Each piece of nigiri goes for $5.
But the nigiri does melt in your mouth.
The fish has a really high level of luscious fattiness to it.
Two of our party, including me, opted for the pre fixe menu.
They don't specifically state what you'll receive.
It just says the amount of nigiri, small plates, etc.
The prix fixe menu is a relatively good value, I think it'd be best to order exactly what you want and adjust as needed.
While the food is good overall I feel like it's lacking a bit of that "oooh" factor.
For the nigiri they even combine customer's orders on one plate.
Then the waiters have to discuss each and every piece to the customer.
I feel like the waiters would have a much easier time if the restaurant weren't so cramped.
We were never really checked up on, but it was mainly because they were so busy trying to bring us our plates and take away the ones we were finished with.
High caliber Japanese cuisine that you'll most likely forget about thirty minutes after leaving.
Chaotic service and atmosphere.
Is the food worth the hassle?
I'm not sure
but it's great on its own.
nigiri.author: Michael H.
nigiri.review:
I have conflicting feelings on my experience at Wako. While the food is high quality I feel like the environment and service aren't up to par.

Wako is definitely a small restaurant. The center of the restaurant is a sushi bar. Table seating is relegated to about five. Even though the restaurant is very small it is easily a five dynamite stick experience. I've been to party sushi restaurants that are quieter. It's a strange dynamic when you're eating high quality food with the soundscape of a super bowl tailgate.

The food is broken down into grilled pates, appetizers, small plates, rolls, and nigiri. This isn't a cheap restaurant. Each piece of nigiri goes for $5. But the nigiri does melt in your mouth. The fish has a really high level of luscious fattiness to it. Two of our party, including me, opted for the pre fixe menu. They don't specifically state what you'll receive. It just says the amount of nigiri, small plates, etc. The prix fixe menu is a relatively good value, I think it'd be best to order exactly what you want and adjust as needed. While the food is good overall I feel like it's lacking a bit of that "oooh" factor. The one standout dish is the chawanmushi.

Service is questionable. Even though there seem to be many servers, the experience felt like an ordeal for both staff and customers. One of the difficulties stems from the number of plates. There are so many plates! For the nigiri they even combine customer's orders on one plate. Then the waiters have to discuss each and every piece to the customer. I feel like the waiters would have a much easier time if the restaurant weren't so cramped. We were never really checked up on, but it was mainly because they were so busy trying to bring us our plates and take away the ones we were finished with.
____
High caliber Japanese cuisine that you'll most likely forget about thirty minutes after leaving. Chaotic service and atmosphere. Is the food worth the hassle? I'm not sure but it's great on its own.

excerpts:
#1 ($43).  
- Small Plates (2) - Braised eggplant and housemade sesame tofu
- Bincho Grill (2) - Grilled Cod
- Nigiri (7) - Bonito, Snow Crab, Uni, Salmon, Otoro, Aji, Hamachi
- Miso Soup - option of red miso or housemade miso.
The highlight of our night was definitely the nigiri, with the otoro being our absolute favorite.
Everything is pre-seasoned so no soy sauce is needed.
In fact, there is no soy sauce on the tables, although I think they will give it to you if you request it.
nigiri.author: Kris L.
nigiri.review:
Love.  Love.  Love.

This is not a Japanese restaurant you should go to if you want something cheap, don't appreciate/like raw fish, or only like untraditional rolls.

A and I went this past Saturday for dinner.  We called a couple of hours earlier to make reservations, although, technically, we didn't need to, because our table was the only one available when we walked in, so we probably would've gotten it anyway.

I have a feeling this place is going to be packed once the word gets out.  So shhh...keep it down.

We both got Omakase Option #1 ($43).  
- Small Plates (2) - Braised eggplant and housemade sesame tofu
- Bincho Grill (2) - Grilled Cod
- Nigiri (7) - Bonito, Snow Crab, Uni, Salmon, Otoro, Aji, Hamachi
- Miso Soup - option of red miso or housemade miso.  

Ala Carte
- Hamachi Yuzu Miso

Everything was high quality and so GOOD!  The highlight of our night was definitely the nigiri, with the otoro being our absolute favorite.  Everything is pre-seasoned so no soy sauce is needed.  In fact, there is no soy sauce on the tables, although I think they will give it to you if you request it.  We did not.

It's a little pricey, but you get what you pay for.  We will definitely be back!

$115. for two.  No drinks.

excerpts: Got the omakase 7 course with extra appetizers and nigiri and of course lots of alcohol!
I must say everything looked delicious and it tastes just as pretty as it looks!
If you lahh dat uni, damn their Hokkaido uni...
So fresh, so gooood!
That sesame tofu...
Gooodness, I can die and go to heaven.
I lovee tofu in general and their tofu was seriously the tastiest I've ever had!
Service was excellent and the atmosphere was comfy and homey!
See you in 2 weeks!
A suggestion - make reservations...
I saw them turn away all walk-ins.
Do it now or regret 5ever.
nigiri.author: Betty P.
nigiri.review: Made a reservation yesterday. Got in today. After eating, made another reservation in 2 weeks! (YES that says a lot for me) Probably my first really authentic, traditional "sushi" experience. Got the omakase 7 course with extra appetizers and nigiri and of course lots of alcohol! I must say everything looked delicious and it tastes just as pretty as it looks! If you lahh dat uni, damn their Hokkaido uni... So fresh, so gooood! That sesame tofu... Gooodness, I can die and go to heaven. I lovee tofu in general and their tofu was seriously the tastiest I've ever had! Service was excellent and the atmosphere was comfy and homey! See you in 2 weeks! A suggestion - make reservations... I saw them turn away all walk-ins. Do it now or regret 5ever. :)

excerpts: Just a tiny little restaurant with no more than 5 tables and a few seats around the sushi bar, the menu at Wako includes few a la carte dishes (only a few appetizers and nigiri), with a pretty great sake menu.
My Omakase was a mix of sushi, sashimi, hot dish, soup, salad, tempura, and dessert.
The other option included only sushi.
Both meals hovered around the same $80/person price point.
The reason why the sushi-only Omakase was more expensive was for the Uni and Wagu beef additions, which were more exclusive and higher grade.
I personally thought the mixed Omakase was fantastic.
I'm a sashimi fan and being able to enjoy both sushi and sashimi made it worth it.
As far as highlights, the tuna sashimi was some of the best tuna I've had in my life.
The texture, freshness, and taste of the tuna was quite simply exquisite.
For sushi highlights, I found both the Toro (fatty tuna), and squid (raw but lightly torched on the top) to be of special significance.
The hot appetizer of the day, miso marinated black cod, was also fantastic.
nigiri.author: Nicole W.
nigiri.review:
Just a tiny little restaurant with no more than 5 tables and a few seats around the sushi bar, the menu at Wako includes few a la carte dishes (only a few appetizers and nigiri), with a pretty great sake menu. 
My Omakase was a mix of sushi, sashimi, hot dish, soup, salad, tempura, and dessert. The other option included only sushi. Both meals hovered around the same $80/person price point. The reason why the sushi-only Omakase was more expensive was for the Uni and Wagu beef additions, which were more exclusive and higher grade. I personally thought the mixed Omakase was fantastic. I'm a sashimi fan and being able to enjoy both sushi and sashimi made it worth it. As far as highlights, the tuna sashimi was some of the best tuna I've had in my life. The texture, freshness, and taste of the tuna was quite simply exquisite. For sushi highlights, I found both the Toro (fatty tuna), and squid (raw but lightly torched on the top) to be of special significance. The hot appetizer of the day, miso marinated black cod, was also fantastic.

excerpts: I am very picky about which nigiri I eat, but I had faith in Tomo's mastery and ended up enjoying fish I previously hated -- like ankimo (monkfish liver) and pretty much any white fish in the sea.
nigiri.author: Brett W.
nigiri.review:
Hands down, the best sushi I've had in SF. Tomo, who used to star at Sanraku, takes it to another level here. I am very picky about which nigiri I eat, but I had faith in Tomo's mastery and ended up enjoying fish I previously hated -- like ankimo (monkfish liver) and pretty much any white fish in the sea. 

It's expensive and you won't find any dragon rolls or any mayo-slathered Americanized stuff (which I actually found to be refreshing for a change), but you won't find better sushi in the City. Plus, Wakako U. (aka Wako) loves the name!

I used to complain that San Francisco was something of a second-rate sushi town. No more!

excerpts: We sat at the bar and did the nigiri omakase menu.
We ordered a couple bottles of sake to go with and it was a near perfect experience.
The chef was super warm and friendly.
He explained each dish as it came out.
I can not wait to come back!!
nigiri.author: ML ..
nigiri.review: We sat at the bar and did the nigiri omakase menu.  We ordered a couple bottles of sake to go with and it was a near perfect experience.  The chef was super warm and friendly.  He explained each dish as it came out.  I can not wait to come back!!

excerpts: The highlight is the nigiri which is basically a sampler of a whole bunch of different fish each one extremely impressive on their own, but each of the earlier courses were equally flavorful.
nigiri.author: Mike H.
nigiri.review:
Food quality and presentation is amazing! Went for the 7 course and it did not disappoint. 

The highlight is the nigiri which is basically a sampler of a whole bunch of different fish each one extremely impressive on their own, but each of the earlier courses were equally flavorful.

If you have a large appetite you may have to add something on top of the main meal. We added the grilled squid and the black cod miso which were both amazing. I cant describe the style in which this was prepared but it was absolutely delicious.

Prices are a little on the high side so be prepared to throw down some money but its definitely worth it. I'd say for 2 people about $200 but if you're not super heavy eaters I think that same amount of food could be good for 3 or 4 on a mother's day or something like that.

We got in early at 6:30 on a Thursday night but by the end of the meal they were turning away guests who didn't have a reservation. If you're coming in for a later dinner or on a more busy night make sure to reserve ahead of time.

excerpts:
had the omakase:

* nigiri/sashimi dishes are very high quality fish: 5 stars
* needs to ease up on the bitter flavors in the warm dish & appetizers: 2.5 stars
*
* 1) requested no wasabi on the nigiri.
it came with wasabi.
when i mentioned it to the waitress she did not offer to correct it.
she merely shrugged her shoulders.
2) it is one thing to keep topping up our tea cup, but when you keep adding hot tea to cold tea, it does not help the tea.
nigiri.author: Sam K.
nigiri.review:
had the omakase:

* nigiri/sashimi dishes are very high quality fish: 5 stars
* needs to ease up on the bitter flavors in the warm dish & appetizers: 2.5 stars
* tempura dish was soggy: 1 star
* 1) requested no wasabi on the nigiri. it came with wasabi. when i mentioned it to the waitress she did not offer to correct it. she merely shrugged her shoulders. 2) it is one thing to keep topping up our tea cup, but when you keep adding hot tea to cold tea, it does not help the tea. the above 2 points = very unprofessional service skills

would definitely go back for sushi/sashimi, but since it is becoming an omakase only menu a return visit is unlikely with its history of inconsistency.

excerpts: We sat at the bar with Chef Tomo, and ordered the nigiri omakase 12 pieces, every piece is a true gem, with well balanced flavors.
nigiri.author: Stephanie G.
nigiri.review: Best sushi place in SF, nice settings with extraordinary attention to details. We sat at the bar with Chef Tomo, and ordered the nigiri omakase 12 pieces, every piece is a true gem, with well balanced flavors.

excerpts: Nigiri was small and prices high, nothing stood out.
nigiri.author: T Y.
nigiri.review:
This was a delicious, memorable Japanese meal.  
The two of us shared about 8 dishes and appetizers off the non-sushi list, and each was delicious and a work of art. The best was the yellowtail dumplings, which were like fishballs in tofu soup.  

Nigiri was small and prices high, nothing stood out.  

Desserts were delicious, but a standard little mochi was $5.  

Dinner for two, no alcohol, was $150.  My friend and his girlfriend came and ate exclusively sashimi/sushi items (no hot dishes) and his bill was $300.  

This place is small so sound really travels...it got unbearably loud when a party of 6 drunk older women came in.

excerpts: There's two omakases to choose from, one with hot dishes and one with just nigiri (the latter being more expensive).
I decided to try to first one.
The hot dishes were good but nothing very special.
The sushi is top quality and would definitely recommend.
The chefs are very nice.
Next time I come I will get the nigiri omakase!
nigiri.author: Jessica Y.
nigiri.review: Wanted to try this place because of the rave reviews and because I usually only go to kusakabe for my pricey sushi fix. There's two omakases to choose from, one with hot dishes and one with just nigiri (the latter being more expensive). I decided to try to first one. The hot dishes were good but nothing very special. The sushi is top quality and would definitely recommend. The chefs are very nice. Next time I come I will get the nigiri omakase!

excerpts: It's pricy(one order for 1pc nigiri), but totally worth it.
The sushi are fresh, well cut and nice decorated, the small plates are delicious too...
wait
, actually everything is good here!!
nigiri.author: Rex M.
nigiri.review: One of the best sushi restaurant in SF. It's pricy(one order for 1pc nigiri), but totally worth it. The sushi are fresh, well cut and nice decorated, the small plates are delicious too...wait, actually everything is good here!!

excerpts: The fish itself was fresh, but I wasn't too wild about the extra wasabi seasoning on the nigiri.
nigiri.author: Orien W.
nigiri.review:
Clean and modern interior, really sharp. Service was excellent and each omakase course was swiftly brought out after the previous one was finished.

The fish itself was fresh, but I wasn't too wild about the extra wasabi seasoning on the nigiri.

excerpts:
Four Course   $43 
                             small plates (2), bincho-grill (1), nigiri (7pcs.), miso soup


Black Cod
The nigiri did not come with a side of soy and wasabi.
nigiri.author: S.K. Y.
nigiri.review:
14.09.18     First Visit of many



Sushi ---------------------  5 (freshness, different preparation)
Non Sushi ---------------  4 1/2 
Interior -------------------  5 The obvious and hidden details
Service ------------------- 5 Stars (I believe I gave only 2 other places this honor)


Note: I have never went to Japan ... 
                so I cannot truly compare it to some of their finest sushi places.
          however I had been to Kiss, Kabuto (old and new locations), etc

Service
   Exceptional
   3 very courteous professional female wait staff
   Almost like having a personal wait staff for your table
 

Had one of WAKO omakase dinner:
      Four Course   $43 
                             small plates (2), bincho-grill (1), nigiri (7pcs.), miso soup


Black Cod
    Marinated in miso


This is a place that is exceptional that is one of the top 2% in the Bay Area
Expect slightly higher price ... BUT you get
   Exceptional service
                      quality ingredients
                      presentation
                      taste

There are too much detail that I will add later:
   Interior ... layout, presentation, dishes, ...
   Yes ... sometimes I  am into detail ... 
              I would observe things like a detective ... I am curious person
              shape, size, placement, texture, blah, blah 
             I would take many pictures of a single subject in different angles for
                    a perfect picture
             This place and food kept me buzy w/o a smart phone (solo run)

I will not bore u with overkilled details
The nigiri did not come with a side of soy and wasabi.
The pieces were treated that u don't need to add anything

Simply ... I am saying it is a personal experience
               Open your mind ... like a child and let it soak in
               Observe the surrounding, table, service, etc

ROUGH DRAFT ...
More to come

ENJOY

Warning:  RESERVE ...

I regret posting this ... now it will be even harder to get in ... sigh ...

excerpts: Stand-outs were the house made sesame tofu and the tasty sashimi / nigiri.
nigiri.author: Jing D.
nigiri.review:
Delicious, traditional Japanese dishes, wonderfully prepared and presented in a cozy but casual yet elegant setting. Excellent and friendly service. 

We got the 7-course omakase ($68) and enjoyed each course. Stand-outs were the house made sesame tofu and the tasty sashimi / nigiri. 

Make a reservation since the restaurant is small. You won't be disappointed.

excerpts: The highlight of them all were the different nigiri sushi pieces.
They were all so good, and they included scallop and a variety of different fishes.
However, I found them to be small.
I guess that's normal for fine-dining = small dishes and high prices.
I had to order a couple of extra nigiri because they're pretty yummy.
We also had a bowl of sashimi, some eggy soup thingy, sweet mousse desserts, miso soup, and some other items I cannot remember what they're made of.
The tuna sashimi was very good.
I'd rank it as high as the nigiri.
The other dishes were okay.
And about the service, it was pretty good, but it depends.
I like the person who was serving us.
She was super friendly and always look happy.
However, another lady there who helped to serve us was kind of stern and seemed a little rude.
Anyhow, I definitely enjoyed it here more so than my wife, but I left this restaurant feeling unfulfilled and went to get McDonald's on the way home.
3.5 stars for me.
nigiri.author: Con N.
nigiri.review: A highly rated, Michelin starred Japanese restaurant... Hmm... that's perfect. My wife loves sushi, and I enjoy Japanese cuisine, so we've got to try the place. I went here recently with my wife for a late Valentine's dinner on a not so perfect day (man, it was raining a lot). I must say overall the food is not bad. We both went for the 9 omasake course. The highlight of them all were the different nigiri sushi pieces. They were all so good, and they included scallop and a variety of different fishes. However, I found them to be small. I guess that's normal for fine-dining = small dishes and high prices. I had to order a couple of extra nigiri because they're pretty yummy. We also had a bowl of sashimi, some eggy soup thingy, sweet mousse desserts, miso soup, and some other items I cannot remember what they're made of. The tuna sashimi was very good. I'd rank it as high as the nigiri. The other dishes were okay. And about the service, it was pretty good, but it depends. I like the person who was serving us. She was super friendly and always look happy. However, another lady there who helped to serve us was kind of stern and seemed a little rude. Anyhow, I definitely enjoyed it here more so than my wife, but I left this restaurant feeling unfulfilled and went to get McDonald's on the way home. 3.5 stars for me.

excerpts: We had the 15 piece nigiri omakase.
Each fish nigiri was fresh and tasty.
The presentation is very beautiful!
The abalone nigiri was a bit too hard for both of us, but everything else was spectacular.
I would definitely come back some other time to try it, again.
nigiri.author: Kevin Y.
nigiri.review: I went here with my girlfriend, and it was amazing! We had the 15 piece nigiri omakase. Each fish nigiri was fresh and tasty. The presentation is very beautiful! The abalone nigiri was a bit too hard for both of us, but everything else was spectacular. I would definitely come back some other time to try it, again.

excerpts: Course 2 - Red snapper and yellowtail nigiri - very fresh and good.
nigiri.author: Amy H.
nigiri.review:
3.5 stars. The $76 7 course omakase is probably about 15-20% overpriced given the portions and the selection.

Course 1 - Hijiki seaweed, pike eel, deep fried scallop, minced toro filled cucumber and somen noodles - pike eel had torch taste and the cucumber overwhelmed the toro flavor. Seaweed and somen were standard and good.

Course 2 - Red snapper and yellowtail nigiri - very fresh and good.

Course 3 - Sweetfish wrapped tamago with a dipping sauce - very simple and a little too bland.

Course 4 - Fried soft shell crab with dashi - nicely fried with a thickened dashi broth sauce.

Course 5 - Mackerel, pike eel, snow crab, scallop, salmon, barracuda, toro, striped jack fish - nothing exceptional or really fresh. I would expect the same quality at another sushi place that is significantly cheaper. They served the pike eel which was already in the first course. Can I have some uni?

Course 6 - Red or white miso - good quality but is this a course?

Course 7 - Panna cotta - standard panna cotta with fruit toppings.

The ambiance is very simple and modern which adds to the experience.

I would not recommend the omakase for the price and selection. The presentation was very nice though. Maybe my expectations were too high from the Yelp ratings.

excerpts: My girl and i ordered a bunch of nigiri and left with a bill over $200.
The nigiri and sashimi pricing is per piece and is very expensive.
he ordered nigiri and i ordered sashimi.
My girl's small plate and sashimi came out quick which was ok
but now she felt obligated to sit and wait for our food, which we figured would come out shortly after.
we waited for a while
then decided to split her small plate which was
AWFUL- there well five tiny cubes of yellow tail and some mixed vegetables.
The yellow tail was extremely fishy and the miso sauce tasted like mayo.
My friend told our waitress that the yellow tail was very fishy and she responded with "thank you for telling me".
It had been roughly 20 min since they served my girls food and she was still waiting for our omakase to eat her sashimi.
40 MIN LATER we had had enough and asked our waitress what was taking so long.
She said that a lot of people ordered at one time and our food would be out soon.
Really?
What is this amateur hour?
These guys have been open for 6+ months and should have this dial in.
We told the waitress we have waited for over an hour and were going to leave.
She said that our food was going to be coming out in 5min...
one piece at a time.
nigiri.author: Ezra K.
nigiri.review:
I've been here 2x. The first time i had dinner here i thought the fish was fresh and the service was standard.  My girl and i ordered a bunch of nigiri and left with a bill over $200. The nigiri and sashimi pricing is per piece and is very expensive. 

I went here with my girl and a friend on friday. My girl wasnt that hungry and ordered a small plate,  hamachi yuzu miso, and an order of sashimi bluefin and yellow tail. My friend and i ordered omakase..he ordered nigiri and i ordered sashimi.  
My girl's small plate and sashimi came out quick which was ok but now she felt obligated to sit and wait for our food, which we figured would come out shortly after.  we waited for a while then decided to split her small plate which was AWFUL- there well five tiny cubes of yellow tail and some mixed vegetables.  The yellow tail was extremely fishy and the miso sauce tasted like mayo.  My friend told our waitress that the yellow tail was very fishy and she responded with "thank you for telling me".  
It had been roughly 20 min since they served my girls food and she was still waiting for our omakase to eat her sashimi.  40 MIN LATER we had had enough and asked our waitress what was taking so long.  She said that a lot of people ordered at one time and our food would be out soon.  Really?  What is this amateur hour?  These guys have been open for 6+ months and should have this dial in.  We told the waitress we have waited for over an hour and were going to leave. She said that our food was going to be coming out in 5min...one piece at a time.  We told her no thank you and walked out. 

Overpriced sushi and bad service.  I will not be going back. There are a million sushi spots in SF that i love, and i'd rather spend my money with them.. and so should you!

excerpts: A5 wagyu nigiri,
x 2- $10 a pop, but totally worth it.

Beef comes cooked (seared I think so eat it while its warm) buttery & so tender
$8 hokkaido uni chawanmushi, - almost as good as aki-san at sushi sho in el cerrito! except this one was highighted due to the hokkaido uni included inside!

so precious and yummy
$8 ankimo - the best ankimo weve ever had.
Most ankimos have the gritty taste in the middle, but this one was SUPER smooth, velvety like foie.

OMG!
fried mackeral fish bone - on the house, one of our favs
$3 tamago- so good, get it last for dessert, not a traditional tamago but has hints and notes of vanilla or coffee, almost like cake!
$5 matcha daifuku- house made mochi with redbean and matcha inside.

heavenly
blueberry panna cotta $5 - good, not mind blowing

, mild tasting like most japo sweets
grilled hokke-
$8 this grilled fish was such a pleasant surprise.
Its a grilled fish filet with bones, grilled over charcoal.
You can tell the care the cook used to grill this fish to perfection, its normally a "dry cured" fish and they grill it
so it comes hot, but it was the most moist and delicately seasoned fish.
Comes with a side of yam.
nigiri.author: Petri Y.
nigiri.review:
Outstanding overall in taste, presentation, service and thoughtfulness behind the meal.

My hubby and I went here on a whim last night, after being so busy at work and not remembering to find a decent reso for our anniversary.

This has been book marked for quite sometime but due to the mixed reviews and higher price point, havent had a chance to take a leap of faith to go just yet....until last night!

We both opted for the four course omakase, consisting of other reviewer's similarly served items:

1) house made tofu with wasabi, dashi stock & seasonal vegetables with bamboo and chestnut-refreshing, a good starter, but best housemade tofu by far is still raku in las vegas. 
2) grilled black cod- fish cooked to perfection, one of the better cod's ive ever had, no bones like previous reviews, excellent and buttery!
3) nigiri- korea halibut, chinook salmon with yuzu gelee, bluefin tuna marinated in jalopeno so, pike mackeral, kani with crab butter, seared hokkaido scallop 
4) red miso soup with himeki mushrooms. Good shari (rice) to fish ratio, edomae style sushi where they paint on the sauce so you dont need soysauce. Everything was very fresh, and delicious favorites were the bluefin tuna marinated in jalopeno soy, so flavorful, and the tuna a very good quality grade tuna. Scallop was also high on the radar, considering normally I dont like scallop, this says a lot. The searing added a good texture to the normally mushy scallop...delish!


add ons to make our belly full!

A5 wagyu nigiri, x 2- $10 a pop, but totally worth it. Beef comes cooked (seared I think so eat it while its warm) buttery & so tender
$8 hokkaido uni chawanmushi, - almost as good as aki-san at sushi sho in el cerrito! except this one was highighted due to the hokkaido uni included inside! so precious and yummy
$8 ankimo - the best ankimo weve ever had. Most ankimos have the gritty taste in the middle, but this one was SUPER smooth, velvety like foie. OMG!
fried mackeral fish bone - on the house, one of our favs
$3 tamago- so good, get it last for dessert, not a traditional tamago but has hints and notes of vanilla or coffee, almost like cake!
$5 matcha daifuku- house made mochi with redbean and matcha inside. heavenly
blueberry panna cotta $5 - good, not mind blowing, mild tasting like most japo sweets
grilled hokke- $8 this grilled fish was such a pleasant surprise. Its a grilled fish filet with bones, grilled over charcoal. You can tell the care the cook used to grill this fish to perfection, its normally a "dry cured" fish and they grill it so it comes hot, but it was the most moist and delicately seasoned fish. Comes with a side of yam. so delicious and healthy.



Hubby is generally a hater of small foods, and was pleasantly surprised at the japo chefs behind the counter. ( I thought they were chinese owned) 

He said overall the quality and presentation was great, and tomosan- the main chef you can tell he cares a lot about his restaurant, the customer experience and thought is put behind each and every bite and it shows.

$180 out the door with 1 small asahi beer. experience, priceless! 
not necessarily a normal day type of meal since it is pricey but for those days you want to splurge....

for those haters who gave it 1 or 2 starts and complained, sorry yall but you dont know what good traditional japanese food is supposed to be about. 
go eat your jive ass rolls elsewhere in the marina =)

excerpts: However, the nigiri was only okay.
Kusakabe excels in that realm
but you are paying significantly more for it.
I like that Wako doesn't enforce the omakase mandate so that allows for more flexibility.
Overall, I enjoy Wako because it's friendlier on my wallet.
nigiri.author: Dorothy L.
nigiri.review: I enjoyed the omakase here.  In fact, I find the warm dishes pretty tastefully executed.  If I had to compare it to my Kusakabe experience, Wako gets the win for warm dishes.   However, the nigiri was only okay.  Kusakabe excels in that realm but you are paying significantly more for it.  I like that Wako doesn't enforce the omakase mandate so that allows for more flexibility.  Overall, I enjoy Wako because it's friendlier on my wallet.

excerpts: Wagyu beef nigiri, yum!
Just melted in your mouth.
This resto is definitely worth for the price!
nigiri.author: Lisa P.
nigiri.review: Wagyu beef nigiri, yum! Just melted in your mouth. This resto is definitely worth for the price!

excerpts: We had the $68 omakase in additional to seven other nigiri per person in order to get full.
Presentation was very pretty, but the palate was too bland for my taste.
nigiri.author: Eve C.
nigiri.review: We had the $68 omakase in additional to seven other nigiri per person in order to get full. Presentation was very pretty, but the palate was too bland for my taste.

excerpts: Out of them I thought the sashimi was fresh, the king crab tempura was tasty, and the main course nigiri sushi were exceptional!
The only thing I would say is that the red miso soup was a little too salty.
I preferred the white miso soup that my girlfriend ordered over the red miso soup.
nigiri.author: Johnston C.
nigiri.review: Came here for dinner with my girlfriend and a friend from out of town.  Been lived in Japan and eaten many Omakaze before, I would say this restaurant is of high standard in both services and food quality.  We ordered the 7 course omakaze for $76 each.  Out of them I thought the sashimi was fresh, the king crab tempura was tasty, and the main course nigiri sushi were exceptional!  The only thing I would say is that the red miso soup was a little too salty.  I preferred the white miso soup that my girlfriend ordered over the red miso soup.

excerpts: Portions are small and the nigiri rice seemed overcooked - a bit like unsweetened rice pudding underneath a morcel of fish.
Even the sake that was recommended wasn't great.
Decor was nice.
But think pay more for the "Japanese-Iness" of the place.
Form over substance.
nigiri.author: Tess A.
nigiri.review: The place looked like it was the real thing. Portions are small and the nigiri rice seemed overcooked - a bit like unsweetened rice pudding underneath a morcel of fish. Even the sake that was recommended wasn't great. Decor was nice.  But think pay more for the "Japanese-Iness" of the place. Form over substance.

excerpts: #5 seven different nigiri sushi #6 miso soup #7 dessert.
We also got chawanmushi in addition.
It was the best chawanmushi I've ever had in the bay area.
It was $8 and it had all sorts of things in it which included a fat piece of uni, white fish tasted like tai fish (not sure), snow crab, and it was just a whole lot of YUMMM.
Not only does the food taste good, I love their presentation.
It makes the meal enjoyable through the palate as well as the eyes.
I know this place will never disappoint.
If you are thinking about trying it out, you should do it soon because it just opened
and it's already super busy.
Weekends are pretty much reservations only because of their limited seating.
nigiri.author: Saki S.
nigiri.review: I would love to give this restaurant more stars! It just recently opened, but I have been here twice already. Both of the times, they went above and beyond my expectations. My family and I got the 7 course meal for the two times we were here. I believe it was $68 for a 7 course meal, but let me tell you, IT WAS WELL WORTH IT! Dish #1 was a three part appetizer: sesame tofu, mushroom medley, and okra and shishito pepper tempura. #2 maguro and seared hamachi sashimi #3 kyoto style grilled belt fish #4 hirame tempura #5 seven different nigiri sushi #6 miso soup #7 dessert. We also got chawanmushi in addition. It was the best chawanmushi I've ever had in the bay area. It was $8 and it had all sorts of things in it which included a fat piece of uni, white fish tasted like tai fish (not sure), snow crab, and it was just a whole lot of YUMMM. Not only does the food taste good, I love their presentation. It makes the meal enjoyable through the palate as well as the eyes. I know this place will never disappoint. If you are thinking about trying it out, you should do it soon because it just opened and it's already super busy. Weekends are pretty much reservations only because of their limited seating.

excerpts: Nigiri averaged out to about $5 per piece, so it's marginally pricier than competitor sushi places in the neighborhood.
Fish was fresh and included some local selections (I believe the uni and salmon were both local), as well as some fish imported from around the world.
nigiri.author: andrew m.
nigiri.review:
Excellent traditional sushi bar, with small menu of beautiful small plates and rolls.

Nigiri averaged out to about $5 per piece, so it's marginally pricier than competitor sushi places in the neighborhood. Fish was fresh and included some local selections (I believe the uni and salmon were both local), as well as some fish imported from around the world. The Norwegian mackerel was among the highlights.

I will definitely be back.

excerpts: Nigiri's were
okay sized
, rice was good but again not worth 7 nigiri, 3 small plates, 1 grill, tempura, miso soup, and tiny ass dessert.
Ordered one of their rolls where you can choose up to 7 items- good but way too small.
Sushi Sam is still by far the best!!
At least their salad order is a good portion size to share.
We ordered some kind of a salad here and it was the size of my palm!
Waste of time and money.
Oh and forgot to mention-
They charge you for wasabi if you ask for extra the 2nd time!!!
Just cuz it's fresh doesn't mean you should charge $3 for so little wasabi!!
Each order of raw fish should come with some sort of wasabi, correct?
But only 2 of our many orders came with wasabi.
We had to ask for more and when we did, they told us that it's $3 for extra....
nigiri.author: Alyce l.
nigiri.review: Made reservations a week in advance for 5 people at 630p. Got here at that time and we were seated near the door where it's a 4 seat table...wtf? We were not sitting comfortable. We asked to move to a roomier spot and they refused. Fine. Whatever...ordered the 7 course omakase for $68....omg...so not worth it!  The first 3 small tiny little plates tasted good but the portion size so small!  Nigiri's were okay sized, rice was good but again not worth 7 nigiri, 3 small plates, 1 grill, tempura, miso soup, and tiny ass dessert. Ordered one of their rolls where you can choose up to 7 items- good but way too small.  Sushi Sam is still by far the best!!  At least their salad order is a good portion size to share. We ordered some kind of a salad here and it was the size of my palm! Waste of time and money. Oh and forgot to mention- They charge you for wasabi if you ask for extra the 2nd time!!! Just cuz it's fresh doesn't mean you should charge $3 for so little wasabi!! Each order of raw fish should come with some sort of wasabi, correct? But only 2 of our many orders came with wasabi. We had to ask for more and when we did, they told us that it's $3 for extra....

excerpts: Had the 15 course nigiri omakase.
Absolutely incredible from start to finish.
I've been fortunate enough to have eaten recently at Sushi Nakazawa (arguably by some accounts the best sushi restaurant in the country), and this place is just as good, if not better.
This is real sushi, no super california dragon 49er cable car rolls, so if you're not into raw fish this is probably not the place to go.
If you want the best of the best sushi in SF, this is the place to go.
So happy to have a new place like this in the Richmond District.
nigiri.author: Luis M.
nigiri.review: Had the 15 course nigiri omakase. Absolutely incredible from start to finish. I've been fortunate enough to have eaten recently at Sushi Nakazawa (arguably by some accounts the best sushi restaurant in the country), and this place is just as good, if not better. This is real sushi, no super california dragon 49er cable car rolls, so if you're not into raw fish this is probably not the place to go. If you want the best of the best sushi in SF, this is the place to go. So happy to have a new place like this in the Richmond District.

excerpts: Japanese restaurants run by other nationalities other than Japanese is fearful if you are looking for Sashimi or Nigiri.
I have gone to other restaurants such as Sanraku Metreon and I would say that the price is quite reasonable for the quality you get.
I will definitely go back again and recommended this restaurant to many others especially the caucasians and other nationalities who really know the true Japanese cuisine like in Japan.
nigiri.author: Frederick K.
nigiri.review: Went to Waka Restaurant on Thursday night with a friend. The inside is so traditional Japanese style that I got the feeling that I was in Japan. The waitresses were very cordial and polite and the Sushi Chef was fun to chat with. Of course the reason I went there was because of the food. The presentation is absolutely beautiful and too good to eat. The fish is very very fresh and the other customers commented on this is what they were impressed with. Japanese restaurants run by other nationalities other than Japanese is fearful if you are looking for Sashimi or Nigiri. I have gone to other restaurants such as Sanraku Metreon and I would say that the price is quite reasonable for the quality you get. I will definitely go back again and recommended this restaurant to many others especially the caucasians and other nationalities who really know the true Japanese cuisine like in Japan.
