excerpts: We enjoyed fresh butterfish and sweetfish nigiri sushi, plus several other items from the menu, which changes daily depending on what fish they can get as fresh as they can.
Among other things, we had the roasted seafood and vegetables, which were served in an abalone shell.
I brought my girlfriend there for her birthday dinner, and while we were not late for our reservation, we didn't have time to go home and dress appropriately for our dinner.
I was dressed in long shorts and felt embarrassed to go into such a classy restaurant, but the waitpersons could not have been more gracious and accommodating to us.
Thank them  for such a wonderful and memorable dinner.
We enjoyed every taste and dish we had, but especially enjoyed the black cod with eggplant, and loved the grilled fish collar, which is sometimes butterfish but happened to be salmon that night.
What an elegant, gracious, lovely meal.
nigiri.author: Susan R.
nigiri.review: I had a wonderful and memorable dinner at Wako on a Saturday night. It's a small restaurant stuck into a crowded part of Clement Street, so find it and make a reservation. You won't want to miss this. We enjoyed fresh butterfish and sweetfish nigiri sushi, plus several other items from the menu, which changes daily depending on what fish they can get as fresh as they can. Among other things, we had the roasted seafood and vegetables, which were served in an abalone shell. I brought my girlfriend there for her birthday dinner, and while we were not late for our reservation, we didn't have time to go home and dress appropriately for our dinner. I was dressed in long shorts and felt embarrassed to go into such a classy restaurant, but the waitpersons could not have been more gracious and accommodating to us. Thank them  for such a wonderful and memorable dinner. We enjoyed every taste and dish we had, but especially enjoyed the black cod with eggplant, and loved the grilled fish collar, which is sometimes butterfish but happened to be salmon that night. What an elegant, gracious, lovely meal.

excerpts: The a la carte menu is different every day, and if yours has a negitoro hand roll, I recommend getting it!!
Instead of the toro being finely chopped up like other places, the toro was actually in pretty thick cuts.
For $7 that was a steal!
negitoro.author: Letty H.
negitoro.review:
I love omakase and Wako definitely won't let you down! It's easy to make reservations on their website or OpenTable!  If you request to sit at the bar, you'll have to call them to let them know & they call you a few days before to confirm it. 

Parking- Plan to come early because parking is difficult. After circling around many times, the waitress told us to try parking on 8th street between Clement and Geary, which is only a few blocks away. We were able to find parking there! 

They have a 9-course and 11-course omakase. We got the 11-course ($130) because we thought the extra items would be worth it! What I like about this place is that they give you the a la carte menu in the beginning so that you can follow along and see exactly what you're getting. 

They give 4 nigiri at a time and separate that with other items! I loved all their nigiri and I was so surprised that they included blue fin tuna belly, Wagyu beef, and uni! Most places I go to, they don't include all of them and if you want it, you have to pay for it separately. Their toro just MELTED in my mouth, even their chu-toro (medium fatty tuna)!! The wagyu beef was not bad, it was a little too torched for my taste, but it was still good! 

The a la carte menu is different every day, and if yours has a negitoro hand roll, I recommend getting it!! Instead of the toro being finely chopped up like other places, the toro was actually in pretty thick cuts. For $7 that was a steal! I definitely will order more of that next time! 

Overall, very friendly and helpful staff. I like the ambiance- they play music, which makes it easier to talk with your party. I definitely recommend making your reservation at the sushi bar because I noticed that a different chef makes the omakase for the tables. They change the menu roughly every other month, and I'll definitely be back!

excerpts: We finished our dinner with sweet tamago (very different from other places) and the misoshiru/akadashi miso soup...which were not as tasty as they looked but cleansed the palette.
Since it's a bday celebration, we ordered four of the perfect/shareable desserts: mango mousse cake, raspberry tarte, and two of the mocha.
It was very filling!
$175 per person
misoshiru.author: Vee V.
misoshiru.review:
Pretty amazing! It's small/cozy but very stylish and inviting. I like the wooden walls. The bathroom smells really nice! Friendly waitresses. Party of 4, ordered just about everything on the menu, so much so that the waitress kept saying "you sure you want more" =) What can I say, we were very hungry. 
Two orders of Omakase Nigiri plus extra orders of mirugai, uni, toro, salmon skin hand roll, etc., etc., But what we REALLY wanted more was ankimo and the best abalone tasting nigiri ever...sadly, they ran out of both. 
We finished our dinner with sweet tamago (very different from other places) and the misoshiru/akadashi miso soup...which were not as tasty as they looked but cleansed the palette. 
Since it's a bday celebration, we ordered four of the perfect/shareable desserts: mango mousse cake, raspberry tarte, and two of the mocha. It was very filling! 
$175 per person

excerpts: If you want to miso soup, I would recommend the misoshiru (traditional miso soup) rather than akadashi (red miso).
misoshiru.author: Rebecca C.
misoshiru.review:
I love this new Japanese restaurant in SF. Small, refined, super friendly staff. If one calls Roku Japanese fusion toward the western end of the spectrum, I would call this Californian Japanese toward the Japanese end of the spectrum.

Everything was done with taste, fabulous presentation, great balance of flavor, and ingenuity.

If you are here with someone, I would suggest to share a 4-course omakase. The nigiris are amazing - seasoned for you already and top quality for fish, rice, and presentation. I even like it better than the ones in Japan since the chef seasons it perfectly to save us Americans from putting too much soy sauce on them. 

If you want to miso soup, I would recommend the misoshiru (traditional miso soup) rather than akadashi (red miso). The second one is a bit more salty and the traditional one has more subtle flavors. 

Skip the rolls - a bit too soft for my taste and the pickles are quite strong. 

The starters for omakase were a great way to ease one into the more elaborate nigiris. The sesame tofu surprised me a bit with a nutty overtone and subtle sweetness. Probably one of the best uncooked version of tofu I have ever tasted. The vegetable dish was delicate and light. 

The peach Panna cotta was fabulous. Not too sweet and not too acidic. Beautifully presented. Just the right creamy/airy balance with quite a bit of depth in the flavor. 

The black cod and the tempura were solid.

excerpts:
Fresh and delicious

akadashi / red miso, sesame tofu, nameko, mitsuba:
akadashi.author: Jack R.
akadashi.review:
Wako has woken me up from my slumber of finding lackluster Japanese restaurants.
Sure my wallet took a $200 hit, but it was worth it.

Since I'm kind of a food snob, I went ahead and chose my own dishes. Like creating my own Lego creation, rather than settling for their Omakase.

Here's a rundown of what I had and my opinion, though I'm sure you know it was great since you've already seen the 5 stars.

negi-toro : Fresh and delicious

akadashi / red miso, sesame tofu, nameko, mitsuba: Tasted like a hearty broth, an acquired taste since it is red miso, but liked it nonetheless

goma dofu / house made sesame tofu: Great homemade dish

ankimo ponzu: Yummy with that delcious glaze

kaisen sunomono: Crunchy and refreshing

en chawanmushi: My favorite out of everything. Digging into the various layers was like finding edible treasure at every turn

kisetsu no kakiage: fresh but passable. I really wanted more of a shrimp tempura dish instead of a fried pancake thing.

All the sushi I bought was super fresh. I ordered one of each seasonal piece nigiri style. (See pic of the menu and of my sushi attached). Each piece was around $5-$8 and was as good as my other favorite Japanese restaurants.

The blueberry panna cotta was small, but had a good creamy texture, and a tart blueberry aftertaste. We enjoyed it immensely.

The service was great, and the teapots were cool. Steel, and each table had a different one.

Reservations strongly recommended, as we saw people getting turned away left and right.

Would I come back again?

Do fish need water?

Hell yeah!

Since it's a bday celebration, we ordered four of the perfect/shareable desserts: mango mousse cake, raspberry tarte, and two of the mocha. It was very filling! 
$175 per person

excerpts: If you want to miso soup, I would recommend the misoshiru (traditional miso soup) rather than akadashi (red miso).
akadashi.author: Rebecca C.
akadashi.review:
I love this new Japanese restaurant in SF. Small, refined, super friendly staff. If one calls Roku Japanese fusion toward the western end of the spectrum, I would call this Californian Japanese toward the Japanese end of the spectrum.

Everything was done with taste, fabulous presentation, great balance of flavor, and ingenuity.

If you are here with someone, I would suggest to share a 4-course omakase. The nigiris are amazing - seasoned for you already and top quality for fish, rice, and presentation. I even like it better than the ones in Japan since the chef seasons it perfectly to save us Americans from putting too much soy sauce on them. 

If you want to miso soup, I would recommend the misoshiru (traditional miso soup) rather than akadashi (red miso). The second one is a bit more salty and the traditional one has more subtle flavors. 

Skip the rolls - a bit too soft for my taste and the pickles are quite strong. 

The starters for omakase were a great way to ease one into the more elaborate nigiris. The sesame tofu surprised me a bit with a nutty overtone and subtle sweetness. Probably one of the best uncooked version of tofu I have ever tasted. The vegetable dish was delicate and light. 

The peach Panna cotta was fabulous. Not too sweet and not too acidic. Beautifully presented. Just the right creamy/airy balance with quite a bit of depth in the flavor. 

The black cod and the tempura were solid.

excerpts:
Tsukidashi (with hint of new year delicacies including kazunoko), assorted sashimi with house made soy sauce, tempura, yaki-mono (baked oyster and scallops), assorted sushi, akadashi miso soup and finished with white wine mouse.
Presentation of food was exquisite.
akadashi.author: Mark M.
akadashi.review:
A gem.  A diamond.   
Ordered the Omakase dinner for $76...
It was a seven course dinner.
Tsukidashi (with hint of new year delicacies including kazunoko), assorted sashimi with house made soy sauce, tempura, yaki-mono (baked oyster and scallops), assorted sushi, akadashi miso soup and finished with white wine mouse.
Presentation of food was exquisite.
Impressed with the ceramic ware used to serve each dish.

As an extra we ordered Satsuma Wagyu nigiri sushi for ten dollars each.
A melt in your mouth experience.

We enjoyed the nice selection of sake..

This restaurant just opened in July of 2014.  Wako is definitely a five star restaurant and to those who put three stars on review because portions are small and complain that his stomach did not get full doesn't really know how to appreciate thoughtfully presented and prepared essence of Japanese kaiseki cuisine.

I wish I lived nearby so that I can be a najimi kyaku.

excerpts:
Tasted like a hearty broth, an acquired taste since it is red miso, but liked it nonetheless

goma dofu / house made sesame tofu: Great homemade dish

ankimo ponzu: Yummy with that delcious glaze
goma dofu.author: Jack R.
goma dofu.review:
Wako has woken me up from my slumber of finding lackluster Japanese restaurants.
Sure my wallet took a $200 hit, but it was worth it.

Since I'm kind of a food snob, I went ahead and chose my own dishes. Like creating my own Lego creation, rather than settling for their Omakase.

Here's a rundown of what I had and my opinion, though I'm sure you know it was great since you've already seen the 5 stars.

negi-toro : Fresh and delicious

akadashi / red miso, sesame tofu, nameko, mitsuba: Tasted like a hearty broth, an acquired taste since it is red miso, but liked it nonetheless

goma dofu / house made sesame tofu: Great homemade dish

ankimo ponzu: Yummy with that delcious glaze

kaisen sunomono: Crunchy and refreshing

en chawanmushi: My favorite out of everything. Digging into the various layers was like finding edible treasure at every turn

kisetsu no kakiage: fresh but passable. I really wanted more of a shrimp tempura dish instead of a fried pancake thing.

All the sushi I bought was super fresh. I ordered one of each seasonal piece nigiri style. (See pic of the menu and of my sushi attached). Each piece was around $5-$8 and was as good as my other favorite Japanese restaurants.

The blueberry panna cotta was small, but had a good creamy texture, and a tart blueberry aftertaste. We enjoyed it immensely.

The service was great, and the teapots were cool. Steel, and each table had a different one.

Reservations strongly recommended, as we saw people getting turned away left and right.

Would I come back again?

Do fish need water?

Hell yeah!

excerpts: The hamachi yuzu miso  - yellowtail, yuzu, lily bulb, miso, celery, carrots $6 was the only great item we ate from the kitchen.
hamachi yuzu miso.author: Kim S.
hamachi yuzu miso.review:
With the lack of authentic, quality sushi restaurants in SF, I can see why Wako has high reviews.  Whenever someone raves about a sushi place in SF, they start with "my favorite roll..." & I stop listening.  Being a purist, sushi is nigiri or maki not California rolls (not authentic) with a combination of random stuff on it.  

We ordered items from both the sushi bar & the kitchen.  The cooked food from the kitchen rate 1-2 stars.  The sushi 3.5 stars.  Overall it was an overpriced dinner.

Kama - the waitress couldn't tell me if it would be Hamachi, basically any type of fish  kama (collar) is served at the same price.  Supposedly it was Hamachi kama that we got.  I've never seen a kama chopped into the 3 small pieces we were served,  It was overcooked, over salted & dry.  1 star.

Butterfish - meh, nothing memorable & def not misoyaki butterfish.  A little piece but at least it wasn't dry.  2 stars.

Tamago - was waaay too sweet!  Definitely wasn't trained on how to prepare it like at Jiro's.  1 star.

The hamachi yuzu miso  - yellowtail, yuzu, lily bulb, miso, celery, carrots $6 was the only great item we ate from the kitchen.

Sake maki, negi-hama maki, hamachi, hotate & saba nigiri were great.  Fresh fish but not great cuts.  Sushi rice was good & served at proper (room) temp.   They don't place soy sauce on the table & take it upon themselves to drizzle it on for you.  That annoys me - like a sushi Nazi who assumes all the customers are too stupid to know how to eat sushi.  I know how to eat sushi & don't drench it in soy sauce, in fact sometimes I'd rather not use soy sauce at all.  3.5 stars.

Service was good - dishes cleared promptly, water kept filled (despite the drought) & they checked on us regularly but not intrusive.  

Tables are close together so if there are loud people seated next to you it can be annoying - we know 1st hand.

TIP:  If you decide to try Wako, book a reservation.  This small place doesn't mark the tables as reserved but most are.  There were many walk-ins who were turned away while we were there.

excerpts:
Ala Carte
- Hamachi Yuzu Miso
hamachi yuzu miso.author: Kris L.
hamachi yuzu miso.review:
Love.  Love.  Love.

This is not a Japanese restaurant you should go to if you want something cheap, don't appreciate/like raw fish, or only like untraditional rolls.

A and I went this past Saturday for dinner.  We called a couple of hours earlier to make reservations, although, technically, we didn't need to, because our table was the only one available when we walked in, so we probably would've gotten it anyway.

I have a feeling this place is going to be packed once the word gets out.  So shhh...keep it down.

We both got Omakase Option #1 ($43).  
- Small Plates (2) - Braised eggplant and housemade sesame tofu
- Bincho Grill (2) - Grilled Cod
- Nigiri (7) - Bonito, Snow Crab, Uni, Salmon, Otoro, Aji, Hamachi
- Miso Soup - option of red miso or housemade miso.  

Ala Carte
- Hamachi Yuzu Miso

Everything was high quality and so GOOD!  The highlight of our night was definitely the nigiri, with the otoro being our absolute favorite.  Everything is pre-seasoned so no soy sauce is needed.  In fact, there is no soy sauce on the tables, although I think they will give it to you if you request it.  We did not.

It's a little pricey, but you get what you pay for.  We will definitely be back!

$115. for two.  No drinks.

excerpts: My girl wasnt that hungry and ordered a small plate,  hamachi yuzu miso, and an order of sashimi bluefin and yellow tail.
My friend and i ordered omakase..
hamachi yuzu miso.author: Ezra K.
hamachi yuzu miso.review:
I've been here 2x. The first time i had dinner here i thought the fish was fresh and the service was standard.  My girl and i ordered a bunch of nigiri and left with a bill over $200. The nigiri and sashimi pricing is per piece and is very expensive. 

I went here with my girl and a friend on friday. My girl wasnt that hungry and ordered a small plate,  hamachi yuzu miso, and an order of sashimi bluefin and yellow tail. My friend and i ordered omakase..he ordered nigiri and i ordered sashimi.  
My girl's small plate and sashimi came out quick which was ok but now she felt obligated to sit and wait for our food, which we figured would come out shortly after.  we waited for a while then decided to split her small plate which was AWFUL- there well five tiny cubes of yellow tail and some mixed vegetables.  The yellow tail was extremely fishy and the miso sauce tasted like mayo.  My friend told our waitress that the yellow tail was very fishy and she responded with "thank you for telling me".  
It had been roughly 20 min since they served my girls food and she was still waiting for our omakase to eat her sashimi.  40 MIN LATER we had had enough and asked our waitress what was taking so long.  She said that a lot of people ordered at one time and our food would be out soon.  Really?  What is this amateur hour?  These guys have been open for 6+ months and should have this dial in.  We told the waitress we have waited for over an hour and were going to leave. She said that our food was going to be coming out in 5min...one piece at a time.  We told her no thank you and walked out. 

Overpriced sushi and bad service.  I will not be going back. There are a million sushi spots in SF that i love, and i'd rather spend my money with them.. and so should you!

But a dollop of uni?
Didn't blend so well to my liking with egg custard!
Blue Fin Tuna cheek on Hotplate (14) was
just so so as I preferred my tuna raw.
But this was just me!
Grilled Ink Squid Legs ($8) was nicely salted and crunchy (
Simmered Golden Eye Snapper Head (9) was a delicacy although your cat would love it too!
I would have preferred it to be served warmer (temp-wise) and was too sweet  for my liking.
Grilled Sanma (pike mackerel) with Matsutake mushroom was definitely a work of art!

kaisen chawanmushi.author: Geoff G.
kaisen chawanmushi.review:
RIDICULOUS! Not the food but the parking! I guess it comes with the territory! Parking on Clement can be insane especially during peak dinner hours. Be prepared to circle the block multiple times as even an illegal space was hard to come by!

Décor is typically Japanese with judicious usage of modern plank-wood on the walls, wooden furnishings and a pretty sushi bar. The vibe was chic and contemporary and more importantly, giving the restaurant a clean look.

As we wanted to try a good cross section of the menu, we opted for a table.

SUSHI:  Wako is high-end. I savored each piece of fish in one mouthful with slow, deliberate bites, as there would be no reruns. Breathe in the pristine freshness, relish how each piece was delicately seasoned and sauced by the chef and notice the textural difference between each fish. Close your eyes if you must lest you might be distracted! Ala Carte nigiri prices are steep. The menu prices are priced per piece, not a pair and you can spend a pretty penny in a hurry! 

Here's a low down of today's nigiri specials and every fish was divine!

1. Hirame (Halibut $6) : a very popular white fish with light and delicate flavor.
2. Shima Aji (Striped Jack $6) : delicious, like a cross between kanpachi (amber jack) and hamachi.
3. Kamasu (Japanese Baracuda $6) : like hirame, it was soft, juicy and light.
4. Kinmedai (Golden Eye Snapper $8) : its texture was not too soft or too crunchy, with a slight sweetness and not fishy.
5. Akamutsu (Rosy Sea Bass $8) : a rare find, not to be missed! A white fish that tasted like toro! (fatty tuna).

The kitchen entrees were equally glorious with some minor hiccups. Even the soy on the table was doctored for better taste. Presentation was the essence.

1. King Crab and Baby Scallop Tempura ($12), light batter and the King Crab were beyond delicious! One piece was given the "isobe" treatment using roasted seaweed (nori) for added flavor. (5/5)
2. Kaisen Chawanmushi ($9 Savory Egg Custard) made with jidori eggs (from specially raised chickens but who cares?). I appreciated the uber smoothness of the custard and the snow crab. But a dollop of uni? Didn't blend so well to my liking with egg custard! (4/5)
3. Blue Fin Tuna cheek on Hotplate (14) was just so so as I preferred my tuna raw. But this was just me! (3/5)
4. Grilled Ink Squid Legs ($8) was nicely salted and crunchy (4/5)
5. Simmered Golden Eye Snapper Head (9) was a delicacy although your cat would love it too! I would have preferred it to be served warmer (temp-wise) and was too sweet  for my liking. (2/5)
6. Grilled Sanma (pike mackerel) with Matsutake mushroom was definitely a work of art! The fish was completely deboned and the mushroom and sweet ginger complemented the umami flavors. Well done! (5/5)

This is the place to come if you are a purist seeking out authenticity and traditionality. I can see careful attention was given to every detail. The server was young, very pleasant although not quite as professional as I would have expected at a high-end place like this. All in all, we had an enjoyable evening!

Gochisosama deshita! (Thank you for the meal!)

excerpts: so we ordered the kaisen chawanmushi - a small hot pot of jidori egg curd, snow crab and uni...
AGAIN absolutely delicious but soooo small!!
I was still soooo hungry.
kaisen chawanmushi.author: Caye Q.
kaisen chawanmushi.review:
I kept building up this place in my head based on all the reviews. Over the summer I was in Tokyo and basically wanted to continue my high of quality sushi. When the date finally came to have dinner here I was more than excited. Stepped into a beautiful, cozy restaurant wrapped in wood. The decor in the place was completely inviting and intimate. The place can only sit about 30 people (you must make reservations and they book up pretty fast..). I really wanted to sit at the bar but it was completely booked even with calling 2 weeks in advance. 

We decided on the 7 course omakase which was comprised of  3 small bites, 1 piece of grilled fish, 7 piece nigiri, 3 small pieces of tempura, miso soup and dessert. 

Completely FRESH AND SIMPLE. Nothing too intricate or bold just simply delicious quality flavors that stayed true to their ingredients. I have to say the sushi nigiri pieces are VERY SMALL; even to Japanese standards. They were probably the smallest pieces of sushi I have ever had.. Even after the 7 courses we were still hungry so we ordered the kaisen chawanmushi - a small hot pot of jidori egg curd, snow crab and uni... AGAIN absolutely delicious but soooo small!! I was still soooo hungry. After dinner  I wanted to run to Genki for a crepe! 

Bottom line this place is OK. Pricey considering I left this place not overly full but definitely worth your while.

excerpts: For food, we ordered the 10 piece nigiri omakase and the kaisen chawanmushi to share.
Food is mediocre at best.
Average.
Nothing stood out to my friend and I.
Maybe just the seared scallop nigiri, but that's out of 10 pieces of nigiri and a small plate.
kaisen chawanmushi.author: Bonny C.
kaisen chawanmushi.review:
My friend and I came here because of high ratings and how much people have been raving about this place. Buuuuut all hype was false unfortunately. 

For food, we ordered the 10 piece nigiri omakase and the kaisen chawanmushi to share. Food is mediocre at best. Average. Nothing stood out to my friend and I. Maybe just the seared scallop nigiri, but that's out of 10 pieces of nigiri and a small plate. 

As for service, we never got a refill on our tea. However, I noticed that the table next to us got an entire pot of tea while we just had a small cup. No one ever stopped by to ask us if we wanted a refill. Also, once the place got busy, we barely even saw our waitress unless they were giving us our food. Even then our food came out pretty fast.

Overall, our experience here was definitely lower than what we had expected. The quality of food is so-so and just average. We were hoping that Wako would prove us wrong, but instead, they proved us right that their food indeed is just average. I'm not saying Wako is bad, but there are definitely other sushi restaurants that serve better fish than here for the amount we paid here. 

Also, just to give you a glimpse of how much we spent, our total bill came out to be about $153 without tip -  $85 per person plus tip. Unfortunately, we won't be coming back.
